column122: VI.--WILLIAM COWPER Cowper has the charm of littleness.

column396: VII.--A NOTE ON ELIZABETHAN PLAYS Voltaire's criticism of Shakespeare as rude and barbarous has only one fault.
column398: Shakespeare, however, is the single dramatist of his age to whom it is not in a measure applicable.
column399: "He was a savage," said Voltaire, "who had imagination.
column400: He has written many happy lines; but his pieces can please only in London and in Canada."
column401: Had this been said of Marlowe, or Chapman, or Jonson (despite his learning), or Cyril Tourneur, one might differ, but one would admit that perhaps there was something in it.
column402: Again, Voltaire's boast that he had been the first to show the French "some pearls which I had found" in the "enormous dunghill" of Shakespeare's plays was the sort of thing that might reasonably have been said by an anthologist who had made selections from Dekker or Beaumont and Fletcher or any dramatist writing under Elizabeth and James except William Shakespeare.
column403: One reads the average Elizabethan play in the certainty that the pearls will be few and the rubbish-heap practically five acts high.
column404: There are, perhaps, a dozen Elizabethan plays apart from Shakespeare's that are as great as his third-best work.
column405: But there are no _Hamlets_ or _Lears_ among them.
column407: There is not even a _Winter's Tale_.
column408: If Lamb, then, had boasted about what he had done for the Elizabethans in general in the terms used by Voltaire concerning himself and Shakespeare his claim would have been just.
column409: Lamb, however, was free from Voltaire's vanity.
column410: He did not feel that he was shedding lustre on the Elizabethans as a patron: he regarded himself as a follower.
column411: Voltaire was infuriated by the suggestion that Shakespeare wrote better than himself; Lamb probably looked on even Cyril Tourneur as his superior.
column412: Lamb was in this as wide of the mark as Voltaire had been.
column413: His reverent praise has made famous among virgins and boys many an old dramatist who but for him would long ago have been thrown to the antiquaries, and have deserved it.

column582: IX.--EDWARD YOUNG AS CRITIC So little is Edward Young read in these days that we have almost forgotten how wide was his influence in the eighteenth century.

column733: He was a wit, an observer of himself and the world about him, a man who wrote letters that have the genius of the essay.
column734: Further, he was Horace Walpole's friend, and (while his father had a devil in him) his mother and his aunts made a circle of quiet tenderness into which he could always retire.
column735: "I do not remember," Mr. Gosse has said of Gray, "that the history of literature presents us with the memoirs of any other poet favoured by nature with so many aunts as Gray possessed."
column736: This delicious sentence contains an important criticism of Gray.
column737: Gray was a poet of the sheltered life.
column738: His genius was shy and retiring.
column739: He had no ambition to thrust himself upon the world.
column740: He kept himself to himself, as the saying is.
column741: He published the _Elegy in a Country Churchyard_ in 1751 only because the editors of the _Magazine of Magazines_ had got hold of a copy and Gray was afraid that they would publish it first.
column742: How lethargic a poet Gray was may be gathered from the fact that he began the _Elegy_ as far back as 1746--Mason says it was begun in August, 1742--and did not finish it until June 12, 1750.
column743: Probably there is no other short poem in English literature which was brooded over for so many seasons.
column744: Nor was there ever a greater justification for patient brooding.
column745: Gray in this poem liberated the English imagination after half a century of prose and rhetoric.
column746: He restored poetry to its true function as the confession of an individual soul.
column747: Wordsworth has blamed Gray for introducing, or at least, assisting to introduce, the curse of poetic diction into English literature.
column748: But poetic diction was in use long before Gray.
column749: He is remarkable among English poets, not for having succumbed to poetic diction, but for having triumphed over it.
column750: It is poetic feeling, not poetic diction, that distinguishes him from the mass of eighteenth-century writers.
column751: It is an interesting coincidence that Gray and Collins should have brought about a poetic revival by the rediscovery of the beauty of evening, just as Mr. Yeats and "A.E."
column752: brought about a poetic revival in our own day by the rediscovery of the beauty of twilight.
column753: Both schools of poetry (if it is permissible to call them schools) found in the stillness of the evening a natural refuge for the individual soul from the tyrannical prose of common day.
column754: There have been critics, including Matthew Arnold, who have denied that the _Elegy_ is the greatest of Gray's poems.
column755: This, I think, can only be because they have been unable to see the poetry for the quotations.
column756: No other poem that Gray ever wrote was a miracle.
column757: _The Bard_ is a masterpiece of imaginative rhetoric.
column758: But the _Elegy_ is more than this.
column759: It is an autobiography and the creation of a world for the hearts of men.
column760: Here Gray delivers the secret doctrine of the poets.
column761: Here he escapes out of the eighteenth century into immortality.
column762: One realizes what an effort it must have been to rise above his century when one reads an earlier version of some of his most famous lines:   Some village Cato (----) with dauntless breast     The little tyrant of his fields withstood;   Some mute, inglorious Tully here may rest;     Some Caesar guiltless of his country's blood.
column763: Could there be a more effective example of the return to reality than we find in the final shape of this verse?
column764: Some village Hampden, that with dauntless breast     The little tyrant of his fields withstood;   Some mute, inglorious Milton here may rest,     Some Cromwell guiltless of his country's blood.
column765: It is as though suddenly it had been revealed to Gray that poetry is not a mere literary exercise but the image of reality; that it does not consist in vain admiration of models far off in time and place, but that it is as near to one as one's breath and one's country.
column766: Not that the _Elegy_ would have been one of the great poems of the world if it had never plunged deeper into the heart than in this verse.
column767: It is a poem of beauty and sorrow that cannot be symbolized by such public figures as Cromwell and Milton.
column768: Here the genius of the parting day, and all that it means to the imagination, its quiet movement and its music, its pensiveness and its regrets, have been given a form more lasting than bronze.
column769: Perhaps the poem owes a part of its popularity to the fact that it is a great homily, though a homily transfigured.
column770: But then does not _Hamlet_ owe a great part of its popularity to the fact that it is (among other things) a great blood-and-thunder play with duels and a ghost?
column771: One of the so-called mysteries of literature is the fact that Gray, having written so greatly, should have written so little.
column772: He spoke of himself as a "shrimp of an author," and expressed the fear that his works might be mistaken for those of "a pismire or a flea."
column773: But to make a mystery of the indolence of a rather timid, idle, and unadventurous scholar, who was blessed with more fastidiousness than passion, is absurd.
column774: To say perfectly once and for all what one has to say is surely as fine an achievement as to keep restlessly trying to say it a thousand times over.
column776: It is said that he did not even let his mother and his aunts know that he wrote poetry.
column777: He lacked boldness, volubility and vital energy.
column779: He would not even take money from his publishers for his poetry.
column780: No wonder that he earned the scorn of Dr. Johnson, who said of him to Boswell, "Sir, he was dull in his company, dull in his closet, dull everywhere.
column781: He was dull in a new way, and that made many think him great."
column782: Luckily, Gray's reserve tempted him into his own heart and into external nature for safety and consolation.
column783: Johnson could see in him only a "mechanical poet."
column784: To most of us he seems the first natural poet in modern literature.
column785: XI.--ASPECTS OF SHELLEY (1) THE CHARACTER HALF-COMIC Shelley is one of the most difficult of men of genius to portray.
column786: It is easy enough to attack him or defend him--to damn him as an infidel or to praise him because he made Harriet Westbrook so miserable that she threw herself into the Serpentine.
column787: But this is an entirely different thing from recapturing the likeness of the man from the nine hundred and ninety-nine anecdotes that are told of him.
column788: These for the most part leave him with an air of absurdity.
column789: In his habit of ignoring facts he appeals again and again to one's sense of the comic, like a drunken man who fails to see the kerb or who walks into a wall.
column790: He was indeed drunken with doctrine.
column791: He lived almost as much from doctrine as from passion.
column792: He pursued theories as a child chases butterflies.
column793: There is a story told of his Oxford days which shows how eccentrically his theories converted themselves into conduct.
column794: Having been reading Plato with Hogg, and having soaked himself in the theory of pre-existence and reminiscence, he was walking on Magdalen Bridge when he met a woman with a child in her arms.
column795: He seized the child, while its mother, thinking he was about to throw it into the river, clung on to it by the clothes.
column796: "Will your baby tell us anything about pre-existence, madam?"
column797: he asked, in a piercing voice and with a wistful look.
column798: She made no answer, but on Shelley repeating the question she said, "He cannot speak."
column799: "But surely," exclaimed Shelley, "he can if he will, for he is only a few weeks old!
column800: He may fancy perhaps that he cannot, but it is only a silly whim; he cannot have forgotten entirely the use of speech in so short a time; the thing is absolutely impossible."
column801: The woman, obviously taking him for a lunatic, replied mildly:  "It is not for me to dispute with you gentlemen, but I can safely declare that I never heard him speak, nor any child, indeed, of his age."
column802: Shelley walked away with his friend, observing, with a deep sigh: "How provokingly close are these new-born babes!"
column803: One can, possibly, discover similar anecdotes in the lives of other men of genius and of men who thought they had genius.
column804: But in such cases it is usually quite clear that the action was a jest or a piece of attitudinizing, or that the person who performed it was, as the vulgar say, "a little above himself."
column805: In any event it almost invariably appears as an abnormal incident in the life of a normal man.
column806: Shelley's life, on the other hand, is largely a concentration of abnormal incidents.
column807: He was habitually "a bit above himself."
column808: In the above incident he may have been consciously behaving comically.
column809: But many of his serious actions were quite as comically extraordinary.
column810: Godwin is related to have said that "Shelley was so beautiful, it was a pity he was so wicked."
column811: I doubt if there is a single literate person in the world to-day who would apply the word "wicked" to Shelley.
column812: It is said that Browning, who had begun as so ardent a worshipper, never felt the same regard for Shelley after reading the full story of his desertion of Harriet Westbrook and her suicide.
column813: But Browning did not know the full story.
column814: No one of us knows the full story.
column815: On the face of it, it looks a peculiarly atrocious thing to desert a wife at a time when she is about to become a mother.
column816: It seems ungenerous, again, when a man has an income of L1,000 a year to make an annual allowance of only L200 to a deserted wife and her two children.
column817: Shelley, however, had not married Harriet for love.
column818: A nineteen-year-old boy, he had run away with a seventeen-year-old girl in order to save her from the imagined tyranny of her father.
column819: At the end of three years Harriet had lost interest in him.
column820: Besides this, she had an intolerable elder sister whom Shelley hated.
column821: Harriet's sister, it is suggested, influenced her in the direction of a taste for bonnet-shops instead of supporting Shelley's exhortations to her that she should cultivate her mind.
column822: "Harriet," says Mr. Ingpen in _Shelley in England_, "foolishly allowed herself to be influenced by her sister, under whose advice she probably acted when, some months earlier, she prevailed upon Shelley to provide her with a carriage, silver plate and expensive clothes."
column823: We cannot help sympathizing a little with Harriet.
column824: At the same time, she was making a breach with Shelley inevitable.
column825: She wished him to remain her husband and to pay for her bonnets, but she did not wish even to pretend to "live up to him" any longer.
column826: As Mr. Ingpen says, "it was love, not matrimony," for which Shelley yearned.
column827: "Marriage," Shelley had once written, echoing Godwin, "is hateful, detestable.
column828: A kind of ineffable, sickening disgust seizes my mind when I think of this most despotic, most unrequired fetter which prejudice has forged to confine its energies."
column829: Having lived for years in a theory of "anti-matrimonialism," he now saw himself doomed to one of those conventional marriages which had always seemed to him a denial of the holy spirit of love.
column830: This, too, at a time when he had found in Mary Godwin a woman belonging to the same intellectual and spiritual race as himself--a woman whom he loved as the great lovers in all the centuries have loved.
column831: Shelley himself expressed the situation in a few characteristic words to Thomas Love Peacock: "Everyone who knows me," he said, "must know that the partner of my life should be one who can feel poetry and understand philosophy.
column832: Harriet is a noble animal, but she can do neither."
column833: "It always appeared to me," said Peacock, "that you were very fond of Harriet."
column834: Shelley replied: "But you did not know how I hated her sister."
column835: And so Harriet's marriage-lines were, torn up, as people say nowadays, like a scrap of paper.
column836: That Shelley did not feel he had done anything inconsiderate is shown by the fact that, within three weeks of his elopement with Mary Godwin, he was writing to Harriet, describing the scenery through which Mary and he had travelled, and urging her to come and live near them in Switzerland.
column837: "I write," his letter runs--     to urge you to come to Switzerland, where you will at least     find one firm and constant friend, to whom your interests will be     always dear--by whom your feelings will never wilfully be injured.
column838: From none can you expect this but me--all else are unfeeling, or     selfish, or have beloved friends of their own, as Mrs. B[oinville],     to whom their attention and affection is confined.
column839: He signed this letter (the Ianthe of whom he speaks was his daughter):     With love to my sweet little Ianthe, ever most affectionately     yours, S. This letter, if it had been written by an amorist, would seem either base or priggish.
column840: Coming from Shelley, it is a miracle of what can only be called innocence.
column841: The most interesting of the "new facts and letters" in Mr. Ingpen's book relate to Shelley's expulsion from Oxford and his runaway match with Harriet, and to his father's attitude on both these occasions.
column842: Shelley's father, backed by the family solicitor, cuts a commonplace figure in the story.
column843: He is simply the conventional grieved parent.
column844: He made no effort to understand his son.
column845: The most he did was to try to save his respectability.
column846: He objected to Shelley's studying for the Bar, but was anxious to make him a member of Parliament; and Shelley and he dined with the Duke of Norfolk to discuss the matter, the result being that the younger man was highly indignant "at what he considered an effort to shackle his mind, and introduce him into life as a mere follower of the Duke."
column847: How unpromising as a party politician Shelley was may be gathered from the fact that in 1811, the same year in which he dined with the Duke, he not only wrote a satire on the Regent _a propos_ of a Carlton House fete, but "amused himself with throwing copies into the carriages of persons going to Carlton House after the fete."
column848: Shelley's methods of propaganda were on other occasions also more eccentric than is usual with followers of dukes.
column849: His journey to Dublin to preach Catholic Emancipation and repeal of the Union was, the beginning of a brief but extraordinary period of propaganda by pamphlet.
column850: Having written a fivepenny pamphlet, _An Address to the Irish People_, he stood in the balcony of his lodgings in Lower Sackville Street, and threw copies to the passers-by.
column851: "I stand," he wrote at the time, "at the balcony of our window, and watch till I see a man _who looks likely_; I throw a book to him."
column852: Harriet, it is to be feared, saw only the comic side of the adventure.
column853: Writing to Elizabeth Hitchener--"the Brown Demon," as Shelley called her when he came to hate her--she said:     I'm sure you would laugh were you to see us give the pamphlets.
column854: We     throw them out of the window, and give them to men that we pass in     the streets.
column855: For myself, I am ready to die of laughter when it is     done, and Percy looks so grave.
column856: Yesterday he put one into a woman's     hood and cloak.
column857: She knew nothing of it, and we passed her.
column858: I could     hardly get on: my muscles were so irritated.
column859: Shelley, none the less, was in regard to Ireland a wiser politician than the politicians, and he was indulging in no turgid or fanciful prose in his _Address_ when he described the Act of Union as "the most successful engine that England ever wielded over the misery of fallen Ireland."
column860: Godwin, with whom Shelley had been corresponding for some time, now became alarmed at his disciple's reckless daring.
column861: "Shelley, you are preparing a scene of blood!"
column862: he wrote to him in his anxiety.
column863: It is evidence of the extent of Godwin's influence over Shelley that the latter withdrew his Irish publications and returned to England, having spent about six weeks on his mission to the Irish people.
column864: Mr. Ingpen has really written a new biography of Shelley rather than a compilation of new material.
column865: The new documents incorporated in the book were discovered by the successors to Mr. William Whitton, the Shelleys' family solicitor, but they can hardly be said to add much to our knowledge of the facts about Shelley.
column866: They prove, however, that his marriage to Harriet Westbrook took place in a Presbyterian church in Edinburgh, and that, at a later period, he was twice arrested for debt.
column867: Mr. Ingpen holds that they also prove that Shelley "appeared on the boards of the Windsor Theatre as an actor in Shakespearean drama."
column868: But we have only William Whitton, the solicitor's words for this, and it is clear that he had been at no pains to investigate the matter.
column869: "It was mentioned to me yesterday," he wrote to Shelley's father in November, 1815, "that Mr. P.B.
column870: Shelley was exhibiting himself on the Windsor stage in the character of Shakespeare's plays, under the figured name of Cooks."
column871: "The character of Shakespeare's plays" sounds oddly, as though Whitton did not know what he was talking about, unless he was referring to allegorical "tableaux vivants" of some sort.
column872: Certainly, so vague a rumour as this--the sort of rumour that would naturally arise in regard to a young man who was supposed to have gone to the bad--is no trustworthy evidence that Shelley was ever "an actor in Shakespearean drama."
column873: At the same time, Mr. Ingpen deserves enthusiastic praise for the untiring pursuit of facts which has enabled him to add an indispensable book to the Shelley library.
column874: I wish that, as he has to some extent followed the events of Shelley's life until the end, he had filled in the details of the life abroad as well as the life in England.
column875: His book is an absorbing biography, but it remains of set purpose a biography with gaps.
column876: He writes, it should be added, in the spirit of a collector of facts rather than of a psychologist.
column877: One has to create one's own portrait of Shelley out of the facts he has brought together.
column878: One is surprised, by the way, to find so devoted a student of Shelley--a student to whom every lover of literature is indebted for his edition of Shelley's letters as well as for the biography--referring to Shelley again and again as "Bysshe."
column879: Shelley's family, it may be admitted, called him "Bysshe."
column880: But never was a more inappropriate name given to a poet who brought down music from heaven.
column881: At the same time, as we read his biography over again, we feel that it is possible that the two names do somehow express two incongruous aspects of the man.
column882: In his life he was, to a great extent, Bysshe; in his poetry he was Shelley.
column883: Shelley wrote _The Skylark_ and _Pan_ and _The West Wind_.
column884: It was Bysshe who imagined that a fat old woman in a train had infected him with incurable elephantiasis.
column885: Mr. Ingpen quotes Peacock's account of this characteristic illusion:     He was continually on the watch for its symptoms; his legs were to     swell to the size of an elephant's, and his skin was to be crumpled     over like goose-skin.
column886: He would draw the skin of his own hands arms,     and neck, very tight, and, if he discovered any deviation from     smoothness, he would seize the person next to him and endeavour, by     a corresponding pressure, to see if any corresponding deviation     existed.
column887: He often startled young ladies in an evening party by this     singular process, which was as instantaneous as a flash of     lightning.
column888: Mr. Ingpen has wisely omitted nothing about Bysshe, however ludicrous.
column889: After reading a biography so unsparing in tragi-comic narrative, however, one has to read _Prometheus_ again in order to recall that divine song of a freed spirit, the incarnation of which we call Shelley.
column890: (2) THE EXPERIMENTALIST Mr. Buxton Forman has an original way of recommending books to our notice.
column891: In an introduction to Medwin's _Life of Percy Bysshe Shelley_ he begins by frankly telling us that it is a bad book, and that the only point of controversy in regard to it is as to the kind of bad book it is.
column892: "Last century," he declares, "produced a plethora of bad books that were valuable, and of fairly good books with no lasting value.
column893: Medwin's distinction is that he left two bad books which were and still are valuable, but whether the _Byron Conversations_ and the _Life of Shelley_ should be called the two most valuable bad books of the century or the two worst valuable books of the century is a hard point in casuistry."
column894: Medwin, we may admit, even if he was not the "perfect idiot" he has been called, would have been a dull fellow enough if he had never met Shelley or Byron.
column895: But he did meet them, and as a result he will live to all eternity, or near it, a little gilded by their rays.
column896: He was not, Mr. Forman contends, the original of the man who "saw Shelley plain" in Browning's lyric.
column897: None the less, he is precisely that man in the imaginations of most of us.
column898: A relative of Shelley, a school friend, an intimate of the last years in Italy, even though we know him to have been one of those men who cannot help lying because they are so stupid, he still fascinates us as a treasury of sidelights on one of the loveliest and most flashing lives in the history of English literature.
column899: Shelley is often presented to us as a kind of creature from fairyland, continually wounded in a struggle with the despotic realities of earth.
column900: Here and in his poetry, however, we see him rather as the herald of the age of science: he was a born experimentalist; he experimented, not only in chemistry, but in life and in politics.
column901: At school, he and his solar microscope were inseparable.
column902: Ardently interested in chemistry, he once, we are told, borrowed a book on the subject from Medwin's father, but his own father sent it back with a note saying: "I have returned the book on chemistry, as it is a forbidden thing at Eton."
column903: During his life at University College, Oxford, his delight in chemical experiments continued.
column904: His chemical operations seemed to an unskilful observer to premise     nothing but disasters.
column905: He had blown himself up at Eton.
column906: He had     inadvertently swallowed some mineral poison, which he declared had     seriously injured his health, and from the effects of which he     should never recover.
column907: His hands, his clothes, his books, and his     furniture, were stained and covered by medical acids--more than one     hole in the carpet could elucidate the ultimate phenomena of     combustion, especially in the middle of the room, where the floor     had also been burnt by his mixing ether or some other fluid in a     crucible, and the honourable wound was speedily enlarged by rents,     for the philosopher, as he hastily crossed the room in pursuit of     truth, was frequently caught in it by the foot.
column908: The same eagerness of discovery is shown in his passion for kite-flying as a boy:     He was fond of flying kites, and at Field Place made an electrical     one, an idea borrowed from Franklin, in order to draw lightning     from The clouds--fire from Heaven, like a new Prometheus.
column909: And his generous dream of bringing science to the service of humanity is revealed in his reflection:     What a comfort it would be to the poor at all times, and especially     in winter, if we could be masters of caloric, and could at will     furnish them with a constant supply!
column910: Shelley's many-sided zeal in the pursuit of truth naturally led him early to invade theology.
column911: From his Eton days, he used to enter into controversies by letter with learned divines.
column912: Medwin declares that he saw one such correspondence in which Shelley engaged in argument with a bishop "under the assumed name of a woman."
column913: It must have been in a somewhat similar mood that "one Sunday after we had been to Rowland Hill's chapel, and were dining together in the city, he wrote to him under an assumed name, proposing to preach to his congregation."
column914: Certainly, Shelley loved mystification scarcely less than he loved truth itself.
column915: He was a romanticist as well as a philosopher, and the reading in his childhood of novels like _Zofloya the Moor_--a work as wild, apparently, as anything Cyril Tourneur ever wrote--excited his imagination to impossible flights of adventure.
column916: Few of us have the endurance to study the effects of this ghostly reading in Shelley's own work--his forgotten novels, _Zastrossi_, and _St.
column917: Irvyne or the Rosicrucian_--but we can see how his life itself borrowed some of the extravagances of fiction.
column918: Many of his recorded adventures are supposed to have been hallucinations, like the story of the "stranger in a military cloak," who, seeing him in a post-office at Pisa, said, "What!
column919: Are you that d--d atheist, Shelley?"
column920: and felled him to the ground.
column921: On the other hand, Shelley's story of his being attacked by a midnight assassin in Wales, after being disbelieved for three-quarters of a century, has in recent years been corroborated in the most unexpected way.
column922: Wild a fiction as his life was in many respects, it was a fiction he himself sincerely and innocently believed.
column923: His imaginative appetite, having devoured science by day and sixpenny romances by night, still remained unsatisfied, and, quite probably, went on to mix up reality and make-believe past all recognition for its next dish.
column924: Francis Thompson, with all respect to many critics, was right when he noted what a complete playfellow Shelley was in his life.
column925: When he was in London after his expulsion from the University, he could throw himself with all his being into childish games like skimming stones on the Serpentine, "counting with the utmost glee the number of bounds, as the flat stones flew skimming over the surface of the water."
column926: He found a perfect pleasure in paper boats, and we hear of his making a sail on one occasion out of a ten-pound note--one of those myths, perhaps, which gather round poets.
column927: It must have been the innocence of pleasure shown in games like these that made him an irresistible companion to so many comparatively prosaic people.
column928: For the idea that Shelley in private life was aloof and unpopular from his childhood up is an entirely false one.
column929: As Medwin points out, in referring to his school-days, he "must have had a rather large circle of friends, since his parting breakfast at Eton cost L50."
column930: Even at the distance of a century, we are still seized by the fascination of that boyish figure with the "stag eyes," so enthusiastically in pursuit of truth and of dreams, of trifles light as air and of the redemption of the human race.
column931: "His figure," Hogg tells us, "was slight and fragile, and yet his bones were large and strong.
column932: He was tall, but he stooped so much that he seemed of low stature."
column933: And, in Medwin's book, we even become reconciled to that shrill voice of his, which Lamb and most other people found so unpleasant.
column934: Medwin gives us nothing in the nature of a portrait of Shelley in these heavy and incoherent pages; but he gives us invaluable materials for such a portrait--in descriptions, for instance, of how he used to go on with his reading, even when he was out walking, and would get so absorbed in his studies that he sometimes asked, "Mary, have I dined?"
column935: More important, as revealing his too exquisite sensitiveness, is the account of how Medwin saw him, "after threading the carnival crowd in the Lung' Arno Corsos, throw himself, half-fainting, into a chair, overpowered by the atmosphere of evil passions, as he used to say, in that sensual and unintellectual crowd."
column936: Some people, on reading a passage like this, will rush to the conclusion that Shelley was a prig.
column937: But the prig is a man easily wounded by blows to his self-esteem, not by the miseries and imperfections of humanity.
column938: Shelley, no doubt, was more convinced of his own rightness than any other man of the same fine genius in English history.
column939: He did not indulge in repentance, like Burns and Byron.
column940: On the other hand, he was not in the smallest degree an egolator.
column941: He had not even such an innocent egoism as Thoreau's.
column942: He was always longing to give himself to the world.
column943: In the Italian days we find him planning an expedition with Byron to rescue, by main force, a man who was in danger of being burnt alive for sacrilege.
column944: He has often been denounced for his heartless treatment of Harriet Westbrook, and, though we may not judge him, it is possible that a better man would have behaved differently.
column945: But it was a mark of his unselfishness, at least, that he went through the marriage service with both his wives, in spite of his principles, that he so long endured Harriet's sister as the tyrant of his house, and that he neglected none of his responsibilities to her, in so far as they were consistent with his deserting her for another woman.
column946: This may seem a _bizarre_ defence, but I merely wish to emphasize the fact that Shelley behaved far better than ninety-nine men out of a hundred would have done, given the same principles and the same circumstances.
column947: He was a man who never followed the line of least resistance or of self-indulgence, as most men do in their love affairs.
column948: He fought a difficult fight all his life in a world that ignored him, except when it was denouncing him as a polluter of Society.
column949: Whatever mistakes we may consider him to have made, we can hardly fail to admit that he was one of the greatest of English Puritans.
column950: (3) THE POET OF HOPE Shelley is the poet for a revolutionary age.
column951: He is the poet of hope, as Wordsworth is the poet of wisdom.
column952: He has been charged with being intangible and unearthly, but he is so only in the sense in which the future is intangible and unearthly.
column953: He is no more unearthly than the skylark or the rainbow or the dawn.
column954: His world, indeed, is a universe of skylarks and rainbows and dawns--a universe in which   Like a thousand dawns on a single night   The splendours rise and spread.
column955: He at once dazzles and overwhelms us with light and music.
column956: He is unearthly in the sense that as we read him we seem to move in a new element.
column957: We lose to some extent the gravity of flesh and find ourselves wandering among stars and sunbeams, or diving under sea or stream to visit the buried day of some wonder-strewn cave.
column958: There are other great poets besides Shelley who have had a vision of the heights and depths.
column959: Compared with him, however, they have all about them something of Goliath's disadvantageous bulk.
column960: Shelley alone retains a boyish grace like David's, and does not seem to groan under the burden of his task.

column1280: XIV.--THE POLITICS OF SWIFT AND SHAKESPEARE (1) SWIFT There are few greater ironies in history than that the modern Conservatives should be eager to claim Swift as one of themselves.

column1283: A Whig, he turned from the Whigs of Queen Anne in disgust, and carried the Tory label for the rest of his life.

column1285: His politics, as every reader of his pamphlets knows, were, above all, the politics of a pacifist and a Home Ruler--the two things most abhorrent to the orthodox Tories of our own time.
column1286: Swift belonged to the Tory Party at one of those rare periods at which it was a peace party.
column1287: _The Conduct of the Allies_ was simply a demand for a premature peace.
column1288: Worse than this, it was a pamphlet against England's taking part in a land-war on the Continent instead of confining herself to naval operations.

column1293: And that Swift was a hater of war, not merely as a party politician, but as a philosopher, is shown by the discourse on the causes of war which he puts into the mouth of Gulliver when the latter is trying to convey a picture of human society to his Houyhnhnm master:     Sometimes the quarrel between two princes is to decide which of     them shall dispossess a third of his dominions, where neither of     them pretends to any right.

column1359: (2) SHAKESPEARE Mr. Whibley goes through history like an electioneering bill-poster.

column1381: The proof of Shakespeare's Toryism, for instance, which he draws from _Troilus and Cressida_, is based on a total misunderstanding of the famous and simple speech of Ulysses about the necessity of observing "degree, priority and place."

column1386: If there are any moderns who come under the noble lash of Ulysses, they must be sought for not among either French or Russian revolutionists, but in the persons of such sound Tories as Sir Edward Carson and such sound patriots as Mr. Lloyd George.

column1388: But how admirably they sum up all the wild statesmanship of these later days in lines which Mr. Whibley, accountably enough, fails to quote:   They tax our policy, and call it cowardice;   Count wisdom as no member of the war;   Forestall prescience, and esteem no act   But that of hand; the still and mental parts--   That do contrive how many hands shall strike,   When fitness calls them on, and know, by measure   Of their observant toil, the enemies' weight--   Why, this hath not a finger's dignity.

column1438: XV.--THE PERSONALITY OF MORRIS One thinks of William Morris as a man who wished to make the world as beautiful as an illuminated manuscript.
column1439: He loved the bright colours, the gold, the little strange insets of landscape, the exquisite craftsmanship of decoration, in which the genius of the medieval illuminators expressed itself.
column1440: His Utopia meant the restoration, not so much of the soul of man, as of the selected delights of the arts and crafts of the Middle Ages.
column1441: His passion for trappings--and what fine trappings!--is admirably suggested by Mr. Cunninghame Graham in his preface to Mr. Compton-Rickett's _William Morris: a Study in Personality_.
column1442: Morris he declares, was in his opinion "no mystic, but a sort of symbolist set in a medieval frame, and it appeared to me that all his love of the old times of which he wrote was chiefly of the setting; of tapestries well wrought; of needlework, rich colours of stained glass falling upon old monuments, and of fine work not scamped."
column1443: To emphasize the preoccupation of Morris with the very handiwork, rather than with the mystic secrets, of beauty is not necessarily to diminish his name.
column1444: He was essentially a man for whom the visible world existed, and in the manner in which he wore himself out in his efforts to reshape the visible world he proved himself one of the great men of his century.
column1445: His life was, in its own way, devotional ever since those years in which Burne-Jones, his fellow-undergraduate at Oxford, wrote to him: "We must enlist you in this Crusade and Holy Warfare against the age."
column1446: Like all revolutions, of course, the Morris revolution was a prophecy rather than an achievement.
column1447: But, perhaps, a prophecy of Utopia is itself one of the greatest achievements of which humanity is capable.
column1448: It is odd that one who spilled out his genius for the world of men should have been so self-sufficing, so little dependent on friendships and ordinary human relationships as Morris is depicted both in Mr. Mackail's biography and Mr. Compton-Rickett's study.
column1449: Obviously, he was a man with whom generosity was a second nature.
column1450: When he became a Socialist, he sold the greater part of his precious library in order to help the cause.
column1451: On the other hand, to balance this, we have Rossetti's famous assertion: "Top"--the general nickname for Morris--"never gives money to a beggar."
column1452: Mr. Mackail, if I remember right, accepted Rossetti's statement as expressive of Morris's indifference to men as compared with causes.
column1453: Mr. Compton-Rickett, however, challenges the truth of the observation.
column1454: "The number of 'beggars,'" he affirms, "who called at his house and went away rewarded were legion."
column1455: Mr. Belfort Bax declares that he kept a drawerful of half-crowns     for foreign anarchists, because, as he explained apologetically:     "They always wanted half-a-crown, and it saved time to have a stock     ready."
column1456: But this is no real contradiction of Rossetti.
column1457: Morris's anarchists represented his life's work to him.
column1458: He did not help them from that personal and irrational charity which made Rossetti want to give a penny to a beggar in the street.
column1459: This may be regarded as a supersubtle distinction; but it is necessary if we are to understand the important fact about Morris that--to quote Mr. Compton-Rickett--"human nature in the concrete never profoundly interested him."
column1460: Enthusiastic as were the friendships of his youth--when he gushed into "dearests" in his letters--we could imagine him as living without friends and yet being tolerably happy.
column1461: He was, as Mr. Compton-Rickett suggests, like a child with a new toy in his discovery of ever-fresh pursuits in the three worlds of Politics, Literature and Art.
column1462: He was a person to whom even duties were Pleasures.
column1463: Mr. Mackail has spoken of him as "the rare distance of a man who, without ever once swerving from truth or duty, knew what he liked and did what he liked, all his life long."
column1464: One thinks of him in his work as a child with a box of paints--an inspired child with wonderful paints and the skill to use them.
column1465: He was such a child as accepts companions with pleasure, but also accepts the absence of companions with pleasure.
column1466: He could absorb himself in his games of genius anywhere and everywhere.
column1467: "Much of his literary work was done on buses and in trains."
column1468: His poetry is often, as it were, the delightful nursery-work of a grown man.
column1469: "His best work," as Mr. Compton-Rickett says, "reads like happy improvisations."

column1471: Once, having come into his studio in a rage, he "took a flying kick at the door, and smashed in a panel."
column1472: "It's all right," he assured the scared model, who was preparing to fly; "it's all right--_something_ had to give way."
column1473: The same violence of impulse is seen in the story of how, on one occasion, when he was staying in the country, he took an artistic dislike to his hostess's curtains, and tore them down during the night.
column1474: His judgments were often much the same kind of untempered emotions as he showed in the matter of the curtains--his complaint, for example, that a Greek temple was "like a table on four legs: a damned dull thing!"
column1475: He was a creature of whims: so much so that, as a boy, he used to have the curse, "Unstable as water, thou shalt not excel," flung at him.
column1476: He enjoyed the expression of knock-out opinions such as: "I always bless God for making anything so strong as an onion!"
column1477: He laughed easily, not from humour so much as from a romping playfulness.
column1478: He took a young boy's pleasure in showing off the strength of his mane of dark brown hair.
column1479: He would get a child to get hold of it, and lift him off the ground by it "with no apparent inconvenience."
column1480: He was at the same time nervous and restless.
column1481: He was given to talking to himself; his hands were never at peace; "if he read aloud, he punched his own head in the exuberance of his emotions."
column1482: Possibly there was something high-strung even about his play, as when, Mr. Mackail tells us, "he would imitate an eagle with considerable skill and humour, climbing on to a chair and, after a sullen pause, coming down with a soft, heavy flop."
column1483: It seems odd that Mr. John Burns could say of this sensitive and capricious man of genius, as we find him saying in Mr. Compton-Rickett's book, that "William Morris was a chunk of humanity in the rough; he was a piece of good, strong, unvarnished oak--nothing of the elm about him."
column1484: But we can forgive Mr. Burns's imperfect judgment in gratitude for the sentences that follow:     There is no side of modern life which he has not touched for good.
column1485: I am sure he would have endorsed heartily the House and Town     Planning Act for which I am responsible.
column1486: Morris, by the way, would have appreciated Mr. Burns's reference to him as a fellow-craftsman: did he not once himself boast of being "a master artisan, if I may claim that dignity"?
column1487: The buoyant life of this craftsman-preacher--whose craftsmanship, indeed, was the chief part of his preaching--who taught the labourers of his age, both by precept and example, that the difference between success and failure in life was the difference between being artisans of loveliness and poor hackworkers of profitable but hideous things--has a unique attractiveness in the history of the latter half of the nineteenth century.
column1488: He is a figure of whom we cannot be too constantly and vividly reminded.
column1489: When I took up Mr. Compton-Rickett's book I was full of hope that it would reinterpret for a new generation Morris's evangelistic personality and ideals.
column1490: Unfortunately, it contains very little of importance that has not already appeared in Mr. Mackail's distinguished biography; and the only interpretation of first-rate interest in the book occurs in the bold imaginative prose of Mr. Cunninghame Graham's introduction.
column1491: More than once the author tells us the same things as Mr. Mackail, only in a less life-like way.
column1492: For example, where Mr. Mackail says of Morris that "by the time he was seven years old he had read all the Waverley novels, and many of Marryat's," Mr. Compton-Rickett vaguely writes: "He was suckled on Romance, and knew his Scott and Marryat almost before he could lisp their names."
column1493: That is typical of Mr. Compton-Rickett's method.
column1494: Instead of contenting himself with simple and realistic sentences like Mr. Mackail's, he aims at--and certainly achieves--a kind of imitative picturesqueness.
column1495: We again see his taste for the high-flown in such a paragraph as that which tells us that "a common bond unites all these men--Dickens, Carlyle, Ruskin and Morris.
column1496: They differed in much; but, like great mountains lying apart in the base, they converge high up in the air."
column1497: The landscape suggested in these sentences is more topsy-turvy than the imagination likes to dwell upon.
column1498: And the criticisms in the book are seldom lightning-flashes of revelation.
column1499: For instance:     A more polished artistry we find in Tennyson; a greater     intellectual grip in Browning; a more haunting magic in Rossetti;     but for easy mastery over his material and general diffusion of     beauty Morris has no superior.
column1500: That, apart from the excellent "general diffusion of beauty," is the kind of conventional criticism that might pass in a paper read to a literary society.
column1501: But somehow, in a critic who deliberately writes a book, we look for a greater and more personal mastery of his authors than Mr. Compton-Rickett gives evidence of in the too facile eloquence of these pages.
column1502: The most interesting part of the book is that which is devoted to personalia.
column1503: But even in the matter of personalia Mr. Cunninghame Graham tells us more vital things in a page of his introduction than Mr. Compton-Rickett scatters through a chapter.
column1504: His description of Morris's appearance, if not a piece of heroic painting, gives us a fine grotesque design of the man:     His face was ruddy, and his hair inclined to red, and grew in waves     like water just before it breaks over a fall.
column1505: His beard was of the     same colour as his hair.
column1506: His eyes were blue and fiery.
column1507: His teeth,     small and irregular, but white except upon the side on which he hew     his pipe, where they were stained with brown.
column1508: When he walked he     swayed a little, not like (_sic_) a sailor sways, but as a man who     lives a sedentary life toddles a little in his gait.
column1509: His ears were     small, his nose high and well-made, his hands and feet small for a     man of his considerable bulk.
column1510: His speech and address were fitting     the man; bold, bluff, and hearty....
column1511: He was quick-tempered and     irritable, swift to anger and swift to reconciliation, and I should     think never bore malice in his life.
column1512: When he talked he seldom looked at you, and his hands were always     twisting, as if they wished to be at work.
column1513: Such was the front the man bore.
column1514: The ideal for which he lived may be summed up, in Mr. Compton-Rickett's expressive phrase, as "the democratization of beauty."
column1515: Or it may be stated more humanly in the words which Morris himself spoke at the grave of a young man who died of injuries received at the hands of the police in Trafalgar Square on "Bloody Sunday."
column1516: "Our friend," he then said:     Our friend who lies here has had a hard life, and met with a hard     death; and, if society had been differently constituted, his life     might have been a delightful, a beautiful, and a happy one.
column1517: It is     our business to begin to organize for the purpose of seeing that     such things shall not happen; to try and make this earth a     beautiful and happy place.
column1518: There you have the sum of all Morris's teaching.
column1519: Like so many fine artists since Plato, he dreamed of a society which would be as beautiful as a work of art.
column1520: He saw the future of society as a radiant picture, full of the bright light of hope, as he saw the past of society as a picture steeped in the charming lights of fancy.
column1521: He once explained Rossetti's indifference to politics by saying that he supposed "it needs a person of hopeful mind to take disinterested notice of politics, and Rossetti was certainly not hopeful."
column1522: Morris was the very illuminator of hope.
column1523: He was as hopeful a man as ever set out with words and colours to bring back the innocent splendours of the Golden Age.
column1524: XVI.--GEORGE MEREDITH (1) THE EGOIST George Meredith, as his friends used to tell one with amusement, was a vain man.
column1525: Someone has related how, in his later years, he regarded it as a matter of extreme importance that his visitors should sit in a position from which they would see his face in profile.
column1526: This is symbolic of his attitude to the world.
column1527: All his life he kept one side of his face hidden.
column1528: Mr. Ellis, who is the son of one of Meredith's cousins, now takes us for a walk round Meredith's chair.
column1529: No longer are we permitted to remain in restful veneration of "a god and a Greek."
column1530: Mr. Ellis invites us--and we cannot refuse the invitation--to look at the other side of the face, to consider the full face and the back of the head.
column1531: He encourages us to feel Meredith's bumps, and no man whose bumps we are allowed to feel can continue for five minutes the pretence of being an Olympian.
column1532: He becomes a human being under a criticizing thumb.
column1533: We discover that he had a genius for imposture, an egoist's temper, and a stomach that fluttered greedily at the thought of dainty dishes.
column1534: We find all those characteristics that prevented him from remaining on good terms first with his father, next with his wife, and then with his son.
column1535: At first, when one reads the full story of Meredith's estrangements through three generations, one has the feeling that one is in the presence of an idol in ruins.
column1536: Certainly, one can never mistake Box Hill for Olympus again.
column1537: On the other hand, let us but have time to accustom ourselves to see Meredith in other aspects than that which he himself chose to present to his contemporaries--let us begin to see in him not so much one of the world's great comic censors, as one of the world's great comic subjects, and we shall soon find ourselves back among his books, reading them no longer with tedious awe, but with a new passion of interest in the figure-in-the-background of the complex human being who wrote them.
column1538: For Meredith was his own great subject.
column1539: Had he been an Olympian he could not have written _The Egoist_ or _Harry Richmond_.
column1540: He was an egoist and pretender, coming of a line of egoists and pretenders, and his novels are simply the confession and apology of such a person.
column1541: Meredith concealed the truth about himself in his daily conversation; he revealed it in his novels.
column1542: He made such a mystery about his birth that many people thought he was a cousin of Queen Victoria's or at least a son of Bulwer Lytton's.
column1543: It was only in _Evan Harrington_ that he told the essentials of the truth about the tailor's shop in Portsmouth above which he was born.
column1544: Outside his art, nothing would persuade him to own up to the tailor's shop.
column1545: Once, when Mr. Clodd was filling in a census-paper for him, Meredith told him to put "near Petersfield" as his place of birth.
column1546: The fact that he was born at Portsmouth was not publicly known, indeed, until some time after his death.
column1547: And not only was there the tailor's shop to live down, but on his mother's side he was the grandson of a publican, Michael Macnamara.
column1548: Meredith liked to boast that his mother was "pure Irish"--an exaggeration, according to Mr. Ellis--but he said nothing about Michael Macnamara of "The Vine."
column1549: At the same time it was the presence not of a bar sinister but of a yardstick sinister in his coat of arms that chiefly filled him with shame.
column1550: When he was marrying his first wife he wrote "Esquire" in the register as a description of his father's profession.
column1551: There is no evidence, apparently, as to whether Meredith himself ever served in the tailor's shop after his father moved from Portsmouth to St. James's Street, London.
column1552: Nothing is known of his life during the two years after his return from the Moravian school at Neuwied.
column1553: As for his hapless father (who had been trained as a medical student but went into the family business in order to save it from ruin), he did not succeed in London any better than in Portsmouth, and in 1849 he emigrated to South Africa and opened a shop in Cape Town.
column1554: It was while in Cape Town that he read Meredith's ironical comedy on the family tailordom, _Evan Harrington; or He Would be a Gentleman_.
column1555: Naturally, he regarded the book (in which his father and himself were two of the chief figures) with horror.
column1556: It was as though George had washed the family tape-measure in public.
column1557: Augustus Meredith, no less than George, blushed for the tape-measure daily.
column1558: Probably, Melchizedek Meredith, who begat Augustus, who begat George, had also blushed for it in his day.
column1559: As the "great Mel" in _Evan Harrington_ he is an immortal figure of genteel imposture.
column1560: His lordly practice of never sending in a bill was hardly that of a man who accepted the conditions of his trade.
column1561: In _Evan Harrington_ three generations of a family's shame were held up to ridicule.
column1562: No wonder that Augustus Meredith, when he was congratulated by a customer on his son's fame, turned away silently with a look of pain.
column1563: The comedy of the Meredith family springs, of course, not from the fact that they were tailors, but that they pretended not to be tailors.
column1564: Whether Meredith himself was more ashamed of their tailoring or their pretentiousness it is not easy to decide.
column1565: Both _Evan Harrington_ and _Harry Richmond_ are in a measure, comedies of imposture, in which the vice of imposture is lashed as fiercely as Moliere lashes the vice of hypocrisy in _Tartuffe_.
column1566: But it may well be that in life Meredith was a snob, while in art he was a critic of snobs.
column1567: Mr. Yeats, in his last book of prose, put forward the suggestion that the artist reveals in his art not his "self" (which is expressed in his life), but his "anti-self," a complementary and even contrary self.
column1568: He might find in the life and works of Meredith some support for his not quite convincing theory.
column1569: Meredith was an egoist in his life, an anti-egoist in his books.
column1570: He was pretentious in his life, anti-pretentious in his books.
column1571: He took up the attitude of the wronged man in his life; he took up the case of the wronged woman in his books.
column1572: In short, his life was vehemently pro-George-Meredith, while his books were vehemently anti-George-Meredith.
column1573: He knew himself more thoroughly, so far as we can discover from his books, than any other English novelist has ever done.
column1574: He knew himself comically, no doubt, rather than tragically.
column1575: In _Modern Love_ and _Richard Feverel_ he reveals himself as by no means a laughing philosopher; but he strove to make fiction a vehicle of philosophic laughter rather than of passionate sympathy.
column1576: Were it not that a great poetic imagination is always at work--in his prose, perhaps, even more than in his verse--his genius might seem a little cold and head-in-the-air.
column1577: But his poet's joy in his characters saves his books from inhumanity.
column1578: As Diana Warwick steps out in the dawn she is not a mere female human being undergoing critical dissection; she is bird-song and the light of morning and the coming of the flowers.
column1579: Meredith had as great a capacity for rapture as for criticism and portraiture.
column1580: He has expressed in literature as no other novelist has done the rapturous vision of a boy in love.
column1581: He knew that a boy in love is not mainly a calf but a poet.
column1582: _Love in a Valley_ is the incomparable music of a boy's ecstasy.
column1583: Much of _Richard Feverel_ is its incomparable prose.
column1584: Rapture and criticism, however, make a more practical combination in literature than in life.
column1585: In literature, criticism may add flavour to rapture; in life it is more than likely to destroy the flavour.
column1586: One is not surprised, then, to learn the full story of Meredith's first unhappy marriage.
column1587: A boy of twenty-one, he married a widow of thirty, high-strung, hot and satirical like himself; and after a depressing sequence of dead babies, followed by the birth of a son who survived, she found life with a man of genius intolerable, and ran away with a painter.
column1588: Meredith apparently refused her request to go and see her when she was dying.
column1589: His imaginative sympathy enabled him to see the woman's point of view in poetry and fiction; it does not seem to have extended to his life.
column1590: Thus, his biography is to a great extent a "showing-up" of George Meredith.
column1591: He proved as incapable of keeping the affection of his son Arthur, as of keeping that of his wife.
column1592: Much as he loved the boy he had not been married again long before he allowed him to become an alien presence.
column1593: The boy felt he had a grievance.
column1594: He said--probably without justice--that his father kept him short of money.
column1595: Possibly he was jealous for his dead mother's sake.
column1596: Further, though put into business, he had literary ambitions--a prolific source of bitterness.
column1597: When Arthur died, Meredith did not even attend his funeral.
column1598: Mr. Ellis has shown Meredith up not only as a husband and a father, but as a hireling journalist and a lark-devouring gourmet.
column1599: On the whole, the poet who could eat larks in a pie seems to me to be a more shocking "great man" than the Radical who could write Tory articles in a newspaper for pay.
column1600: At the same time, it is only fair to say that Meredith remains a sufficiently splendid figure in.
column1601: Mr. Ellis's book even when we know the worst about him.
column1603: It was at least a prodigal one.
column1604: As poet, novelist, correspondent, and conversationalist, he leaves an impression of beauty, wit, and power in a combination without a precedent.
column1605: (2) THE OLYMPIAN UNBENDS Lady Butcher's charming _Memoirs of George Meredith_ is admittedly written in reply to Mr. Ellis's startling volume.
column1606: It seems to me, however, that it is a supplement rather than a reply.
column1607: Mr. Ellis was not quite fair to Meredith as a man, but he enabled us to understand the limitations which were the conditions of Meredith's peculiar genius.
column1608: Many readers were shocked by the suggestion that characters, like countries, must have boundaries.
column1609: Where Mr. Ellis failed, in my opinion, was not in drawing these as carefully as possible, but in the rather unfriendly glee with which, one could not help feeling, he did so.
column1610: It is also true that he missed some of the grander mountain-peaks in Meredith's character.
column1611: Lady Butcher, on the other hand, is far less successful than Mr. Ellis in drawing a portrait which makes us feel that now we understand something of the events that gave birth to _The Egoist_ and _Richard Feverel_ and _Modern Love_.
column1612: Her book tells us nothing of the seed-time of genius, but is a delightful account of its autumn.
column1613: At the same time it helps to dissipate one ridiculous popular fallacy about Meredith.
column1614: Meredith, like most all the wits, has been accused of straining after image and epigram.
column1615: Wit acts as an irritant on many people.
column1616: They forget the admirable saying of Coleridge: "Exclusive of the abstract sciences, the largest and worthiest portion of our knowledge consists of aphorisms; and the greatest of men is but an aphorism."
column1617: They might as well denounce a hedge for producing wild roses or a peacock for growing tail feathers with pretty eyes as a witty writer for flowering into aphorism, epigram and image.
column1618: Even so artificial a writer as Wilde had not to labour to be witty.
column1619: It has often been laid to his charge that his work smells of the lamp, whereas what is really the matter with it is that it smells of the drawing-room gas.
column1620: It was the result of too much "easy-goingness," not of too much strain.
column1621: As for Meredith, his wit was the wit of an abounding imagination.
column1622: Lady Butcher gives some delightful examples of it.
column1623: He could not see a baby in long robes without a witty image leaping into his mind.
column1624: He said he adored babies "in the comet stage."
column1625: Of a lady of his acquaintance he said: "She is a woman who has never had the first tadpole wriggle of an idea," adding, "She has a mind as clean and white and flat as a plate: there are no eminences in it."
column1626: Lady Butcher tells of a picnic-party on Box Hill at which Meredith was one of the company.
column1627: "After our picnic ... it came on to rain, and as we drearily trudged down the hill with cloaks and umbrellas, and burdened with our tea baskets, Mr. Meredith, with a grimace, called out to a passing friend: 'Behold!
column1629: If Meredith is to some extent an obscure author, it is clear that this was not due to his over-reaching himself in laborious efforts after wit.
column1630: His obscurity is not that of a man straining after expression, but the obscurity of a man deliberately hiding something.
column1631: Meredith believed in being as mysterious as an oracle.
column1632: He assumed the Olympian manner, and objected to being mistaken for a frequenter of the market-place.
column1633: He was impatient of ordinary human witlessness, and spoke to his fellows, not as man to man, but as Apollo from his seat.
column1634: This was probably a result of the fact that his mind marched much too fast for the ordinary man to keep pace with it.
column1635: "How I leaped through leagues of thought when I could walk!"
column1636: he once said when he had lost the power of his legs.
column1637: Such buoyancy of the imagination and intellect separated him more and more from a world in which most of the athletics are muscular, not mental; and he began to take a malicious pleasure in exaggerating the difference that already existed between himself and ordinary mortals.
column1638: He dressed his genius in a mannerism, and, as he leaped through his leagues of thought, the flying skirts of his mannerism were all that the average reader panting desperately after him could see.
column1639: Shakespeare and the greatest men of genius are human enough to wait for us, and give us time to recover our breath.
column1640: Meredith, however, was a proud man, and a mocker.
column1641: In the ordinary affairs of life, Lady Butcher tells us, he was so proud that it was difficult to give him even trifling gifts.
column1642: "I remember," she says, "bringing him two silver flat poached-egg spoons from Norway, and he implored me to take them back with me to London, and looked much relieved when I consented to do so!"
column1643: He would always "prefer to bestow rather than to accept gifts."
column1644: Lady Butcher, replying to the charge that he was ungrateful, suggests that "no one should expect an eagle to be grateful."
column1645: But then, neither can one love an eagle, and one would like to be able to love the author of _Love in a Valley_ and _Richard Feverel_.
column1646: Meredith was too keenly aware what an eagle he was.
column1647: Speaking of the reviewers who had attacked him, he said: "They have always been abusing me.
column1650: It is quite true, but it was a superior person who said it.
column1651: Meredith, however, among his friends and among the young, loses this air of superiority, and becomes something of a radiant romp as well as an Olympian.
column1652: Lady Butcher's first meeting with him took place when she was a girl of thirteen.
column1653: She was going up Box Hill to see the sun rise with a sixteen-year-old cousin, when the latter said: "I know a madman who lives on Box Hill.
column1654: He's quite mad, but very amusing; he likes walks and sunrises.
column1655: Let's go and shout him up!"
column1656: It does Meredith credit that he got out of bed and joined them, "his nightshirt thrust into brown trousers."
column1657: Even when the small girl insisted on "reading aloud to him one of the hymns from Keble's _Christian Year_," he did not, as the saying is, turn a hair.
column1658: His attachment to his daughter Mariette--his "dearie girl," as he spoke of her with unaffected softness of phrase--also helps one to realize that he was not all Olympian.
column1659: Meredith, the condemner of the "guarded life," was humanly nervous in guarding his own little daughter.
column1660: "He would never allow Mariette to travel alone, even the very short distance by train from Box Hill to Ewell; a maid had always to be sent with her or to fetch her.
column1661: He never allowed her to walk by herself."
column1662: One likes Meredith the better for Lady Butcher's picture of him as a "harassed father."
column1663: One likes him, too, as he converses with his dogs, and for his thoughtfulness in giving some of his MSS., including that of _Richard Feverel_, to Frank Cole, his gardener, in the hope that "some day the gardener would be able to sell them" and so get some reward for his devotion.
column1664: As to the underground passages in Meredith's life and character, Lady Butcher is not concerned with them.
column1665: She writes of him merely as she knew him.
column1666: Her book is a friend's tribute, though not a blind tribute.
column1667: It may not be effective as an argument against those who are bent on disparaging the greatest lyrical wit in modern English literature.
column1668: But it will be welcomed by those for whom Meredith's genius is still a bubbling spring of good sense and delight.
column1669: (3) THE ANGLO-IRISH ASPECT Meredith never wrote a novel which was less a novel than _Celt and Saxon_.
column1670: It is only a fragment of a book.
column1671: It is so much a series of essays and sharp character-sketches, however, that the untimely fall of the curtain does not greatly trouble us.
column1672: There is no excitement of plot, no gripping anxiety as to whether this or that pair of lovers will ever reach the altar.
column1673: Philip O'Donnell and Patrick, his devoted brother, and their caricature relative, the middle-aged Captain Con, all interest us as they abet each other in the affairs of love or politics, or as they discuss their native country or the temperament of the country which oppresses it; but they are chiefly desirable as performers in an Anglo-Irish fantasia, a Meredithian piece of comic music, with various national anthems, English, Welsh, and Irish, running through and across it in all manner of guises, and producing all manner of agreeable disharmonies.
column1674: In the beginning we have Patrick O'Donnell, an enthusiast, a Celt, a Catholic, setting out for the English mansion of the father of Adiante Adister to find if the girl cannot be pleaded over to reconsider her refusal of his brother Philip.
column1675: He arrives in the midst of turmoil in the house, the cause of it being a hasty marriage which Adiante had ambitiously contracted with a hook-nosed foreign prince.
column1676: Patrick, a broken-hearted proxy, successfully begs her family for a miniature of the girl to take back to his brother, but he falls so deeply in love with her on seeing the portrait that his loyalty to Philip almost wavers, when the latter carelessly asks him to leave the miniature on a more or less public table instead of taking it off to the solitude of his own room for a long vigil of adoration.
column1677: In the rest of the story we have an account of the brothers in the London house of Captain Con, the happy husband married to a stark English wife of mechanical propriety--a rebellious husband, too, when in the sociable atmosphere of his own upper room, amid the blackened clay pipes and the friendly fumes of whiskey, he sings her praises, while at the same time full of grotesque and whimsical criticisms of all those things, Saxon and more widely human, for which she stands.
column1678: There is a touch of farce in the relations of these two, aptly symbolized by the bell which rings for Captain Con, and hastens him away from his midnight eloquence with Patrick and Philip.
column1680: I haven't heard the tinkler for months.
column1681: It signifies she's cold in her bed.
column1682: The thing called circulation is unknown to her save by the aid of outward application, and I'm the warming-pan, as legitimately as I should be, I'm her husband and her Harvey in one.'"
column1683: It is in the house of Captain Con, it should be added, that Philip and Patrick meet Jane Mattock, the Saxon woman; and the story as we have it ends with Philip invalided home from service in India, and Jane, a victim of love, catching "glimpses of the gulfs of bondage, delicious, rose-enfolded, foreign."
column1684: There are nearly three hundred pages of it altogether, some of them as fantastic and lyrical as any that Meredith ever wrote.
column1685: As one reads _Celt and Saxon_, however, one seems to get an inkling of the reason why Meredith has so often been set down as an obscure author.
column1686: It is not entirely that he is given to using imagery as the language of explanation--a subtle and personal sort of hieroglyphics.
column1687: It is chiefly, I think, because there is so little direct painting of men and women in his books.
column1688: Despite his lyricism, he had something of an X-ray's imagination.
column1689: The details of the modelling of a face, the interpreting lines and looks, did not fix themselves with preciseness on his vision enabling him to pass them on to us with the surface reality we generally demand in prose fiction.
column1690: It is as though he painted some of his men and women upon air: they are elusive for all we know of their mental and spiritual processes.
column1691: Even though he is at pains to tell us that Diana's hair is dark, we do not at once accept the fact but are at liberty to go on believing she is a fair woman, for he himself was general rather than insistently particular in his vision of such matters.
column1692: In the present book, again, we have a glimpse of Adiante in her miniature--"this lighted face, with the dark raised eyes and abounding auburn tresses, where the contrast of colours was in itself thrilling," "the light above beauty distinguishing its noble classic lines and the energy of radiance, like a morning of chivalrous promise, in the eyes"--and, despite the details mentioned, the result is to give us only the lyric aura of the woman where we wanted a design.
column1693: Ultimately, these women of Meredith's become intensely real to us--the most real women, I think, in English fiction--but, before we come to handshaking terms with them, we have sometimes to go to them over bogs and rocky places with the sun in our eyes.
column1694: Before this, physically, they are apt to be exquisite parts of a landscape, sharers of a lyric beauty with the cherry-trees and the purple crocuses.
column1695: Coming to the substance of the book--the glance from many sides at the Irish and English temperaments--we find Meredith extremely penetrating in his criticism of John Bullishness, but something of a foreigner in his study of the Irish character.
column1696: The son of an Irishwoman, he chose an Irishwoman as his most conquering heroine, but he writes of the race as one who has known the men and women of it entirely, or almost entirely, in an English setting--a setting, in other words, which shows up their strangeness and any surface eccentricities they may have, but does not give us an ordinary human sense of them.
column1697: Captain Con is vital, because Meredith imagined him vitally, but when all is said and done, he is largely a stage-Irishman, winking over his whiskey that has paid no excise--a better-born relative of Captain Costigan.
column1698: Politically, _Celt and Saxon_ seems to be a plea for Home Rule--Home Rule, with a view towards a "consolidation of the union."
column1699: Its diagnosis of the Irish difficulty is one which has long been popular with many intellectual men on this side of the Irish Sea.
column1700: Meredith sees, as the roots of the trouble, misunderstanding, want of imagination, want of sympathy.
column1701: It has always seemed curious to me that intelligent men could persuade themselves that Ireland was chiefly suffering from want of understanding and want of sympathy on the part of England, when all the time her only ailment has been want of liberty.
column1702: To adapt the organ-grinder's motto,   Sympathy without relief   Is like mustard without beef.
column1703: As a matter of fact, Meredith realized this, and was a friend to many Irish national movements from the Home Rule struggle down to the Gaelic League, to the latter of which the Irish part of him sent a subscription a year or two ago.
column1704: He saw things from the point of view of an Imperial Liberal idealist, however, not of a Nationalist.
column1705: In the result, he did not know the every-day and traditional setting of Irish life sufficiently well to give us an Irish Nationalist central figure as winning and heroic, even in his extravagances, as, say, the patriotic Englishman, Neville Beauchamp.
column1706: At the same time, one must be thankful for a book so obviously the work of a great abundant mind--a mind giving out its criticisms like flutters of birds--a heroic intellect always in the service of an ideal liberty, courage, and gracious manners--a characteristically island brain, that was yet not insular.
column1707: XVII--OSCAR WILDE Oscar Wilde is a writer whom one must see through in order to appreciate.
column1708: One must smash the idol in order to preserve the god.
column1709: If Mr. Ransome's estimate of Wilde in his clever and interesting and seriously-written book is a little unsatisfactory, it is partly because he is not enough of an iconoclast.
column1710: He has not realized with sufficient clearness that, while Wilde belonged to the first rank as a wit, he was scarcely better than second-rate as anything else.
column1711: Consequently, it is not Wilde the beau of literature who dominates his book.
column1712: Rather, it is Wilde the egoistic,--aesthetic philosopher, and Wilde the imaginative artist.
column1713: This is, of course, as Wilde would have liked it to be.
column1714: For, as Mr. Ransome says, "though Wilde had the secret of a wonderful laughter, he preferred to think of himself as a person with magnificent dreams."
column1715: Indeed, so much was this so, that it is even suggested that, if _Salome_ had not been censored, the social comedies might never have been written.
column1716: "It is possible," observes Mr. Ransome, "that we owe _The Importance of Being Earnest_ to the fact that the Censor prevented Sarah Bernhardt from playing _Salome_ at the Palace Theatre."
column1717: If this conjecture is right, one can never think quite so unkindly of the Censor again, for in _The Importance of Being Earnest_, and in it alone, Wilde achieved a work of supreme genius in its kind.
column1718: It is as lightly-built as a house of cards, a frail edifice of laughter for laughter's sake.
column1719: Or you might say that, in the literature of farce, it has a place as a "dainty rogue in porcelain."
column1720: It is even lighter and more fragile than that.
column1721: It is a bubble, or a flight of bubbles.
column1722: It is the very ecstasy of levity.
column1723: As we listen to Lady Bracknell discussing the possibility of parting with her daughter to a man who had been "born, or at least bred, in a handbag," or as we watch Jack and Algernon wrangling over the propriety of eating muffins in an hour of gloom, we seem somehow to be caught up and to sail through an exhilarating mid-air of nonsense.
column1724: Some people will contend that Wilde's laughter is always the laughter not of the open air but of the salon.
column1725: But there is a spontaneity in the laughter of _The Importance of Being Earnest_ that seems to me to associate it with running water and the sap rising in the green field.
column1726: It is when he begins to take Wilde seriously as a serious writer that one quarrels with Mr. Ransome.
column1727: Wilde was much better at showing off than at revealing himself, and, as the comedy of showing off is much more delightful than the solemn vanity of it, he was naturally happiest as a wit and persifleur.
column1728: On his serious side he ranks, not as an original artist, but as a popularizer--the most accomplished popularizer, perhaps, in English literature.
column1729: He popularized William Morris, both his domestic interiors and his Utopias, in the aesthetic lectures and in _The Soul of Man under Socialism_--a wonderful pamphlet, the secret of the world-wide fame of which Mr. Ransome curiously misses.
column1730: He popularized the cloistral aestheticism of Pater and the cultural egoism of Goethe in _Intentions_ and elsewhere.
column1731: In _Salome_ he popularized the gorgeous processionals of ornamental sentences upon which Flaubert had expended not the least marvellous portion of his genius.
column1732: Into an age that guarded respectability more closely than virtue and ridiculed beauty because it paid no dividend came Wilde, the assailant of even the most respectable ugliness, parrying the mockery of the meat tea with a mockery that sparkled like wine.
