column2546: It was the chorus of imitative rapture over Synge a few years ago that helped most to bring about a speedy reaction against him.
column2547: Synge was undoubtedly a man of fine genius--the genius of gloomy comedy and ironic tragedy.
column2548: His mind delved for strangenesses in speech and imagination among people whom the new age had hardly touched, and his discoveries were sufficiently magnificent to make the eyes of any lover of language brighten.
column2549: His work showed less of the mastery of life, however, than of the mastery of a theme.
column2550: It was a curious by-world of literature, a little literature of death's-heads, and, therefore, no more to be mentioned with the work of the greatest than the stories of Villiers de l'Isle-Adam.
column2551: Unfortunately, some disturbances in Dublin at the first production of _The Playboy_ turned the play into a battle-cry, and the artists, headed by Mr. Yeats, used Synge to belabour the Philistinism of the mob.
column2552: In the excitement of the fight they were soon talking about Synge as though Dublin had rejected a Shakespeare.
column2553: Mr. Yeats even used the word "Homeric" about him--surely the most inappropriate word it would be possible to imagine.
column2554: Before long Mr. Yeats's enthusiasm had spread to England, where people who ignored the real magic of Synge's work, as it is to be found in _Riders to the Sea_, _In the Shadow of the Glen_, and _The Well of the Saints_, went into ecstasies over the inferior _Playboy_.
column2555: Such a boom meant not the appreciation of Synge but a glorification of his more negligible work.
column2556: It was almost as if we were to boom Swinburne on the score of his later political poetry.
column2557: Criticism makes for the destruction of such booms.
column2558: I do not mean that the critic has not the right to fling about superlatives like any other man.
column2559: Criticism, in one aspect, is the art of flinging about superlatives finely.
column2560: But they must be personal superlatives, not boom superlatives.
column2561: Even when they are showered on an author who is the just victim of a boom--and, on a reasonable estimate, at least fifty per cent of the booms have some justification--they are as unbeautiful as rotten apples unless they have this personal kind of honesty.
column2562: It may be thought that an attitude of criticism like this may easily sink into Pharisaism--a sort of "superior-person" aloofness from other people.
column2563: And no doubt the critic, like other people, needs to beat his breast and pray, "God be merciful to me, a--critic."
column2564: On the whole, however, the critic is far less of a professional faultfinder than is sometimes imagined.
column2565: He is first of all a virtue-finder, a singer of praise.
column2566: He is not concerned with getting rid of the dross except in so far as it hides the gold.
column2567: In other words, the destructive side of criticism is purely a subsidiary affair.
column2568: None of the best critics have been men of destructive minds.
column2569: They are like gardeners whose business is more with the flowers than with the weeds.
column2570: If I may change the metaphor, the whole truth about criticism is contained in the Eastern proverb which declares that "Love is the net of Truth."
column2571: It is as a lover that the critic, like the lyric poet and the mystic, will be most excellently symbolized.
column2572: XXIV.--BOOK REVIEWING I notice that in Mr.
column2573: Seekers' _Art and Craft of Letters_ series no volume on book-reviewing has yet been announced.
column2574: A volume on criticism has been published, it is true, but book-reviewing is something different from criticism.
column2575: It swings somewhere between criticism on the one hand and reporting on the other.
column2576: When Mr. Arthur Bourchier a few years ago, in the course of a dispute about Mr. Walkley's criticisms, spoke of the dramatic critic as a dramatic reporter, he did a very insolent thing.
column2577: But there was a certain reasonableness in his phrase.
column2578: The critic on the Press is a news-gatherer as surely as the man who is sent to describe a public meeting or a strike.
column2579: Whether he is asked to write a report on a play of Mr. Shaw's or an exhibition of etchings by Mr.
column2580: Bone or a volume of short stories by Mr. Conrad or a speech by Mr. Asquith or a strike on the Clyde, his function is the same.
column2581: It is primarily to give an account, a description, of what he has seen or heard or read.
column2582: This may seem to many people--especially to critics--a degrading conception of a book-reviewer's work.
column2583: But it is quite the contrary.
column2584: A great deal of book-reviewing at the present time is dead matter.
column2585: Book-reviews ought at least to be alive as news.
column2586: At present everybody is ready to write book-reviews.
column2587: This is because nearly everybody believes that they are the easiest kind of thing to write.
column2588: People who would shrink from offering to write poems or leading articles or descriptive sketches of football matches, have an idea that reviewing books is something with the capacity for which every man is born, as he is born with the capacity for talking prose.
column2589: They think it is as easy as having opinions.
column2590: It is simply making a few remarks at the end of a couple of hours spent with a book in an armchair.
column2591: Many men and women--novelists, barristers, professors and others--review books in their spare time, as they look on this as work they can do when their brains are too tired to do anything which is of genuine importance.
column2592: A great deal of book-reviewing is done contemptuously, as though to review books well were not as difficult as to do anything else well.
column2593: This is perhaps due in some measure to the fact that, for the amount of hard work it involves, book-reviewing is one of the worst-paid branches of journalism.
column2594: The hero of Mr. Beresford's new novel, _The Invisible Event_, makes an income of L250 a year as an outside reviewer, and it is by no means every outside reviewer who makes as much as that from reviewing alone.
column2595: It is not that there is not an immense public which reads book-reviews.
column2597: O'Connor showed an admirable journalistic instinct when twenty years or so ago he filled the front page of the _Weekly Sun_ with a long book-review.
column2598: The sale of the _Times Literary Supplement_, since it became a separate publication, is evidence that, for good or bad, many thousands of readers have acquired the habit of reading criticism of current literature.
column2599: But I do not think that the mediocre quality of most book-reviewing is due to low payment.
column2600: It is a result, I believe, of a wrong conception of what a book-review should be.
column2601: My own opinion is that a review should be, from one point of view, a portrait of a book.
column2602: It should present the book instead of merely presenting remarks about the book.
column2603: In reviewing, portraiture is more important than opinion.
column2604: One has to get the reflexion of the book, and not a mere comment on it, down on paper.
column2605: Obviously, one must not press this theory of portraiture too far.
column2606: It is useful chiefly as a protest against the curse of comment.
column2607: Many clever writers, when they come to write book-reviews, instead of portraying the book, waste their time in remarks to the effect that the book should never have been written, and so forth.
column2608: That, in fact, is the usual attitude of clever reviewers when they begin.
column2609: They are so horrified to find that Mr. William Le Queux does not write like Dostoevsky and that Mrs. Florence Barclay lacks the grandeur of AEschylus that they run amok among their contemporaries with something of the furious destructiveness of Don Quixote on his adventures.
column2610: It is the noble intolerance of youth; but how unreasonable it is!
column2611: Suppose a portrait-painter were suddenly to take his sitter by the throat on the ground that he had no right to exist.
column2612: One would say to him that that was not his business: his business is to take the man's existence for granted, and to paint him until he becomes in a new sense alive.
column2613: If he is worthless, paint his worthlessness, but do not merely comment on it.
column2614: There is no reason why a portrait should be flattering, but it should be a portrait.
column2615: It may be a portrait in the grand matter, or a portrait in caricature: if it expresses its subject honestly and delightfully, that is all we can ask of it.
column2616: A critical portrait of a book by Mr.
column2617: Le Queux may be amazingly alive: a censorious comment can only be dull.
column2618: Mr. Hubert Bland was at one time an almost ideal portrait-painter of commonplace novels.
column2619: He obviously liked them, as the caricaturist likes the people in the street.
column2620: The novels themselves might not be readable, but Mr.
column2622: He could reveal their characteristics in a few strokes, which would tell you more of what you wanted to know about them than a whole dictionary of adjectives of praise and blame.
column2623: One could tell at a glance whether the book had any literary value, whether it was worth turning to as a stimulant, whether it was even intelligent of its kind.
column2624: One would not like to see Mr.
column2625: Bland's method too slavishly adopted by reviewers: it was suitable only for portraying certain kinds of books.
column2626: But it is worth recalling as the method of a man who, dealing with books that were for the most part insipid and worthless, made his reviews delightfully alive as well as admirably interpretative.
column2627: The comparison of a review to a portrait fixes attention on one essential quality of a book-review.
column2628: A reviewer should never forget his responsibility to his subject.
column2629: He must allow nothing to distract him from his main task of setting down the features of his book vividly and recognizably.
column2630: One may say this even while admitting that the most delightful book-reviews of modern times--for the literary causeries of Anatole France may fairly be classified as book-reviews--were the revolt of an escaped angel against the limitations of a journalistic form.
column2631: But Anatole France happens to be a man of genius, and genius is a justification of any method.
column2632: In the hands of a pinchbeck Anatole France, how unendurable the review conceived as a causerie would become!
column2633: Anatole France observes that "all books in general, and even the most admirable, seem to me infinitely less precious for what they contain than for what he who reads puts into them."
column2634: That, in a sense, is true.
column2635: But no reviewer ought to believe it.
column2636: His duty is to his author: whatever he "puts into him" is a subsidiary matter.
column2637: "The critic," says Anatole France again, "must imbue himself thoroughly with the idea that every book has as many different aspects as it has readers, and that a poem, like a landscape, is transformed in all the eyes that see it, in all the souls that conceive it."
column2638: Here he gets nearer the idea of criticism as portraiture, and practically every critic of importance has been a portrait-painter.
column2639: In this respect Saint-Beuve is at one with Macaulay, Pater with Matthew Arnold, Anatole France (occasionally) with Henry James.
column2640: They may portray authors rather than books, artists rather than their work, but this only means that criticism at its highest is a study of the mind of the artist as reflected in his art.
column2641: Clearly, if the reviewer can paint the portrait of an author, he is achieving something better even than the portrait of a book.
column2642: But what, at all costs, he must avoid doing is to substitute for a portrait of one kind or another the rag-bag of his own moral, political or religious opinions.
column2643: It is one of the most difficult things in the world for anyone who happens to hold strong opinions not to make the mind of Shakespeare himself a pulpit from which to roar them at the world.
column2644: Reviewers with theories about morality and religion can seldom be induced to come to the point of portraiture until they have enjoyed a preliminary half-column of self-explanation.
column2645: In their eyes a review is a moral essay rather than an imaginative interpretation.
column2646: In dissenting from this view, one is not pleading for a race of reviewers without moral or religious ideas, or even prepossessions.
column2647: One is merely urging that in a review, as in a novel or a play, the moral should be seated at the heart instead of sprawling all over the surface.
column2648: In the well-worn phrase it should be implicit, not explicit.
column2649: Undoubtedly a rare critic of genius can make an interesting review-article out of a statement of his own moral and political ideas.
column2650: But that only justifies the article as an essay, not as a review.
column2651: To many reviewers--especially in the bright days of youth--it seems an immensely more important thing to write a good essay than a good review.
column2652: And so it is, but not when a review is wanted.
column2653: It is a far, far better thing to write a good essay about America than a good review of a book on America.
column2654: But the one should not be substituted for the other.
column2655: If one takes up a review of a book on America by Mr. Wells or Mr. Bennett, it is in ninety-nine cases out of a hundred in order to find out what the author thinks, not what the reviewer thinks.
column2656: If the reviewer begins with a paragraph of general remarks about America--or, worse still, about some abstract thing like liberty--he is almost invariably wasting paper.
column2657: I believe it is a sound rule to destroy all preliminary paragraphs of this kind.
column2658: They are detestable in almost all writing, but most detestable of all in book-reviews, where it is important to plunge all at once into the middle of things.
column2659: I say this, though there is an occasional book-reviewer whose preliminary paragraphs I would not miss for worlds.
column2660: But one has even known book-reviewers who wrote delightful articles, though they made scarcely any reference to the books under review at all.
column2661: To my mind, nothing more clearly shows the general misconception of the purpose of a book-review than the attitude of the majority of journalists to the quotational review.
column2662: It is the custom to despise the quotational review--to dismiss is as mere "gutting."
column2663: As a consequence, it is generally very badly done.
column2664: It is done as if under the impression that it does not matter what quotations one gives so long as one fills the space.
column2665: One great paper lends support to this contemptuous attitude towards quotational criticism by refusing to pay its contributors for space taken up by quotations.
column2666: A London evening newspaper was once guilty of the same folly.
column2667: A reviewer on the staff of the latter confessed to me that to the present day he finds it impossible, without an effort, to make quotations in a review, because of the memory of those days when to quote was to add to one's poverty.
column2668: Despised work is seldom done well, and it is not surprising that it is almost more seldom that one finds a quotational review well done than any other sort.
column2669: Yet how critically illuminating a quotation may be!
column2670: There are many books in regard to which quotation is the only criticism necessary.
column2671: Books of memoirs and books of verse--the least artistic as well as the most artistic forms of literature--both lend themselves to it.
column2672: To criticize verse without giving quotations is to leave one largely in ignorance of the quality of the verse.
column2673: The selection of passages to quote is at least as fine a test of artistic judgment as any comment the critic can make.
column2674: In regard to books of memoirs, gossip, and so forth, one does not ask for a test of delicate artistic judgment.
column2675: Books of this kind should simply be rummaged for entertaining "news."
column2676: To review them well is to make an anthology of (in a wide sense) amusing passages.
column2677: There is no other way to portray them.
column2678: And yet I have known a very brilliant reviewer take a book of gossip about the German Court and, instead of quoting any of the numerous things that would interest people, fill half a column with abuse of the way in which the book was written, of the inconsequence of the chapters, of the second-handedness of many of the anecdotes.
column2679: Now, I do not object to any of these charges being brought.
column2680: It is well that "made" books should not be palmed off on the public as literature.
column2681: On the other hand, a mediocre book (from the point of view of literature or history) is no excuse for a mediocre review.
column2682: No matter how mediocre a book is, if it is on a subject of great interest, it usually contains enough vital matter to make an exciting half-column.
column2683: Many reviewers despise a bad book so heartily that, instead of squeezing every drop of interest out of it, as they ought to do, they refrain from squeezing a single drop of interest out of it.
column2684: They are frequently people who suffer from anecdotophobia.
column2685: "Scorn not the anecdote" is a motto that might be modestly hung up in the heart of every reviewer.
column2686: After all, Montaigne did not scorn it, and there is no reason why the modern journalist should be ashamed of following so respectable an example.
column2687: One can quite easily understand how the gluttony of many publishers for anecdotes has driven writers with a respect for their intellect into revolt.
column2688: But let us not be unjust to the anecdote because it has been cheapened through no fault of its own.
column2689: We may be sure of one thing.
column2690: A review--a review, at any rate, of a book of memoirs or any similar kind of non-literary book--which contains an anecdote is better than a review which does not contain an anecdote.
column2691: If an anecdotal review is bad, it is because it is badly done, not because it is anecdotal.
column2692: This, one might imagine, is too obvious to require saying; but many men of brains go through life without ever being able to see it.
column2693: One of the chief virtues of the anecdote is that it brings the reviewer down from his generalizations to the individual instances.
column2694: Generalizations mixed with instances make a fine sort of review, but to flow on for a column of generalizations without ever pausing to light them into life with instances, concrete examples, anecdotes, is to write not a book-review but a sermon.
column2695: Of the two, the sermon is much the easier to write: it does not involve the trouble of constant reference to one's authorities.
column2696: Perhaps, however, someone with practice in writing sermons will argue that the sermon without instances is as somniferous as the book-review with the same want.
column2697: Whether that it so or not, the book-review is not, as a rule, the place for abstract argument.
column2698: Not that one wants to shut out controversy.
column2699: There is no pleasanter review to read than a controversial review.
column2700: Even here, however, one demands portrait as well as argument.
column2701: It is, in nine cases out of ten, waste of time to assail a theory when you can portray a man.
column2702: It always seems to me to be hopelessly wrong for the reviewer of biographies, critical studies, or books of a similar kind, to allow his mind to wander from the main figure in the book to the discussion of some theory or other that has been incidentally put forward.
column2703: Thus, in a review of a book on Stevenson, the important thing is to reconstruct the figure of Stevenson, the man and the artist.
column2704: This is much more vitally interesting and relevant than theorizing on such questions as whether the writing of prose or of poetry is the more difficult art, or what are the essential characteristics of romance.
column2705: These and many other questions may arise, and it is the proper task of the reviewer to discuss them, so long as their discussion is kept subordinate to the portraiture of the central figure.
column2706: But they must not be allowed to push the leading character in the whole business right out of the review.
column2707: If they are brought in at all, they must be brought in, like moral sentiments, inoffensively by the way.
column2708: In pleading that a review should be a portrait of a book to a vastly greater degree than it is a direct comment on the book, I am not pleading that it should be a mere bald summary.
column2709: The summary kind of review is no more a portrait than is the Scotland Yard description of a man wanted by the police.
column2710: Portraiture implies selection and a new emphasis.
column2711: The synopsis of the plot of a novel is as far from being a good review as is a paragraph of general comment on it.
column2712: The review must justify itself, not as a reflection of dead bones, but by a new life of its own.
column2713: Further, I am not pleading for the suppression of comment and, if need be, condemnation.
column2714: But either to praise or condemn without instances is dull.
column2715: Neither the one thing nor the other is the chief thing in the review.
column2716: They are the crown of the review, but not its life.
column2717: There are many critics to whom condemnation of books they do not like seems the chief end of man.
column2718: They regard themselves as engaged upon a holy war against the Devil and his works.
column2719: Horace complained that it was only poets who were not allowed to be mediocre.
column2720: The modern critic--I should say the modern critic of the censorious kind, not the critic who looks on it as his duty to puff out meaningless superlatives over every book that appears--will not allow any author to be mediocre.
column2721: The war against mediocrity is a necessary war, but I cannot help thinking that mediocrity is more likely to yield to humour than to contemptuous abuse.
column2722: Apart from this, it is the reviewer's part to maintain high standards for work that aims at being literature, rather than to career about, like a destroying angel, among books that have no such aim.
column2723: Criticism, Anatole France has said, is the record of the soul's adventures among masterpieces.
column2725: is for the most part the record of the soul's adventures among books that are the reverse of masterpieces.
column2726: What, then, are his standards to be?
column2727: Well, a man must judge linen as linen, cotton as cotton, and shoddy as shoddy.
column2728: It is ridiculous to denounce any of them for not being silk.
column2729: To do so is not to apply high standards so much as to apply wrong standards.
column2730: One has no right as a reviewer to judge a book by any standard save that which the author aims at reaching.
column2731: As a private reader, one has the right to say of a novel by Mr. Joseph Hocking, for instance: "This is not literature.
column2735: I do not say that these sentences can be fairly used of any of Mr. Hocking's novels.
column2736: I merely take him as an example of a popular novelist who would be bound to be condemned if judged by comparison with Flaubert or Meredith or even Mr. Galsworthy.
column2737: But the reviewer is not asked to state whether he finds Mr. Hocking readable so much as to state the kind of readableness at which Mr. Hocking aims and the measure of his success in achieving it.
column2738: It is the reviewer's business to discover the quality of a book rather than to keep announcing that the quality does not appeal to him.
column2739: Not that he need conceal the fact that it has failed to appeal to him, but he should remember that this is a comparatively irrelevant matter.
column2740: He may make it as clear as day--indeed, he ought to make it as clear as day, if it is his opinion--that he regards the novels of Charles Garvice as shoddy, but he ought also to make it clear whether they are the kind of shoddy that serves its purpose.
column2741: Is this to lower literary standards?
column2742: I do not think so, for, in cases of this kind, one is not judging literature, but popular books.
column2743: Those to whom popular books are anathema have a temperament which will always find it difficult to fall in with the limitations of the work of a general reviewer.
column2744: The curious thing is that this intolerance of easy writing is most generally found among those who are most opposed to intolerance in the sphere of morals.
column2745: It is as though they had escaped from one sort of Puritanism into another.
column2746: Personally, I do not see why, if we should be tolerant of the breach of a moral commandment, we should not be equally tolerant of the breach of a literary commandment.
column2747: We should gently scan, not only our brother man, but our brother author.
column2748: The aesthete of to-day, however, will look kindly on adultery, but show all the harshness of a Pilgrim Father in his condemnation of a split infinitive.
column2749: I cannot see the logic of this.
column2750: If irregular and commonplace people have the right to exist, surely irregular and commonplace books have a right to exist by their side.
column2751: The reviewer, however, is often led into a false attitude to a book, not by its bad quality, but by some irrelevant quality--some underlying moral or political idea.
column2752: He denounces a novel the moral ideas of which offend him, without giving sufficient consideration to the success or failure of the novelist in the effort to make his characters live.
column2753: Similarly, he praises a novel with the moral ideas of which he agrees, without reflecting that perhaps it is as a tract rather than as a work of art that it has given him pleasure.
column2754: Both the praise and blame which have been heaped upon Mr. Kipling are largely due to appreciation or dislike of his politics.
column2755: The Imperialist finds his heart beating faster as he reads _The English Flag_, and he praises Mr. Kipling as an artist when it is really Mr. Kipling as a propagandist who has moved him.
column2756: The anti-Imperialist, on the other hand, is often led by detestation of Mr. Kipling's politics to deny even the palpable fact that Mr. Kipling is a very brilliant short-story teller.
column2757: It is for the reviewer to raise himself above such prejudices and to discover what are Mr. Kipling's ideas apart from his art, and what is his art apart from his ideas.
column2758: The relation between one and the other is also clearly a relevant matter for discussion.
column2759: But the confusion of one with the other is fatal.
column2760: In the field of morals we are perhaps led astray in our judgments even more frequently than in matters of politics.
column2761: Mr. Shaw's plays are often denounced by critics whom they have made laugh till their sides ached, and the reason is that, after leaving the theatre, the critics remember that they do not like Mr, Shaw's moral ideas.
column2762: In the same way, it seems to me, a great deal of the praise that has been given to Mr. D.H. Lawrence as an artist ought really to be given to him as a distributor of certain moral ideas.
column2763: That he has studied wonderfully one aspect of human nature, that he can describe wonderfully some aspects of external nature, I know; but I doubt whether his art is fine enough or sympathetic enough to make enthusiastic anyone who differs from the moral attitude, as it may be called, of his stories.
column2764: This is the real test of a work of art--has it sufficient imaginative vitality to capture the imagination of artistic readers who are not in sympathy with its point of view?
column2765: The _Book of Job_ survives the test: it is a book to the spell of which no imaginative man could be indifferent, whether Christian, Jew or atheist.
column2766: Similarly, Shelley is read and written about with enthusiasm by many who hold moral, religious, and political ideas directly contrary to his own.
column2767: Mr. Kipling's _Recessional_, with its sombre imaginative glow, its recapturing of Old Testament prides and fears, commands the praise of thousands to whom much of the rest of his poetry is the abominable thing.
column2768: It is the reviewer's task to discover imagination even in those who are the enemies of the ideas he cherishes.
column2769: In so far as he cannot do this, he fails in his business as a critic of the arts.
column2770: It may be said in answer to all this, however, that to appeal for tolerance in book-reviewers is not necessary.
column2771: The Press is already overcrowded with laudations of commonplace books.
column2772: Not a day passes but at least a dozen books are praised as having "not a dull moment," being "readable from cover to cover," and as reminding the reviewer of Stevenson, Meredith, Oscar Wilde, Paul de Kock, and Jane Austen.
column2773: That is not the kind of tolerance which one is eager to see.
column2774: That kind of review is scarcely different from a publisher's advertisement.
column2775: Besides, it usually sins in being mere summary and comment, or even comment without summary.
column2776: It is a thoughtless scattering of acceptable words and is as unlike the review conceived as a portrait as is the hostile kind of commentatory review which I have been discussing.
column2777: It is generally the comment of a lazy brain, instead of being, like the other, the comment of a clever brain.
column2778: Praise is the vice of the commonplace reviewer, just as censoriousness is the vice of the more clever sort.
column2779: Not that one wishes either praise or censure to be stinted.
column2780: One is merely anxious not to see them misapplied.
column2781: It is a vice, not a virtue, of reviewing to be lukewarm either in the one or the other.
column2782: What one desires most of all in a reviewer, after a capacity to portray books, is the courage of his opinions, so that, whether he is face to face with an old reputation like Mr. Conrad's or a new reputation like Mr. Mackenzie's, he will boldly express his enthusiasms and his dissatisfactions without regard to the estimate of the author, which is, for the moment, "in the air."
column2783: What seems to be wanted, then, in a book-reviewer is that, without being servile, he should be swift to praise, and that, without being censorious, he should have the courage to blame.
column2784: While tolerant of kinds in literature, he should be intolerant of pretentiousness.
column2785: He should be less patient, for instance, of a pseudo-Milton than of a writer who frankly aimed at nothing higher than a book of music-hall songs.
column2786: He should be more eager to define the qualities of a book than to heap comment upon comment.
column2787: If--I hope the image is not too strained--he draws a book from the life, he will produce a better review than if he spends his time calling it names, whether foul or fair.
column2788: But what of the equipment of the reviewer?
column2791: One of the faults of modern reviewing seems to me to be that the standards of many critics are derived almost entirely from the literature of the last thirty years.
column2792: This is especially so with some American critics, who rush feverishly into print with volumes spotted with the names of modern writers as Christmas pudding is spotted with currants.
column2793: To read them is to get the impression that the world is only a hundred years old.
column2794: It seems to me that Matthew Arnold was right when he urged men to turn to the classics for their standards.
column2795: His definition of the classics may have been too narrow, and nothing could be more utterly dead than a criticism which tries to measure imaginary literature by an academic standard or the rules of Aristotle.
column2796: But it is only those to whom the classics are themselves dead who are likely to lay this academic dead hand on new literature.
column2797: Besides, even the most academic standards are valuable in a world in which chaos is hailed with enthusiasm both in art and in politics.
column2798: But, when all is said, the taste which is the essential quality of a critic is something with which he is born.

column4681: XII.--THE WISDOM OF COLERIDGE (1) COLERIDGE AS CRITIC Coleridge was the thirteenth child of a rather queer clergyman.
column4683: John Coleridge was queer enough in having thirteen children: he was queerer still in being the author of a Latin grammar in which he renamed the "ablative" the "quale-quare-quidditive case."
column4684: Coleridge was thus born not only with an unlucky number, but trailing clouds of definitions.

column4730: Hence, criticism at its highest is not a theorist's attempt to impose iron laws on writers: it is an attempt to capture the secret of that "inner light" and of those who possess it and to communicate it to others.

column4928: XIV.--THE POLITICS OF SWIFT AND SHAKESPEARE (1) SWIFT There are few greater ironies in history than that the modern Conservatives should be eager to claim Swift as one of themselves.

column5045: He makes us sympathize with Coriolanus in his heroism, in his sufferings, in his return to his better nature, in his death; but from Shakespeare's point of view, as from most men's the Nietzschean arrogance which led Coriolanus to become a traitor to his city is a theme for sadness, not (as apparently with Mr. Whibley) for enthusiasm.
column5046: "Shakespeare," cries Mr. Whibley, as he quotes some of Coriolanus's anti-popular speeches, "will not let the people off.
column5047: He pursues it with an irony of scorn."
column5048: "There in a few lines," he writes of some other speeches, "are expressed the external folly and shame of democracy.
column5049: Ever committed to the worse cause, the people has not even the courage of its own opinions."
column5050: It would be interesting to know whether in Mr. Whibley's eyes Coriolanus's hatred of the people is a sufficiently splendid virtue to cover his guilt in becoming a traitor.
column5051: That good Tories have the right to become traitors was a gospel preached often enough in regard to the Ulster trouble before the war.
column5052: It may be doubted, however, whether Shakespeare was sufficiently a Tory to foresee the necessity of such a gospel in _Coriolanus_.
column5053: Certainly, the mother of Coriolanus, who was far from being a Radical, or even a mild Whig, preached the very opposite of the gospel of treason.
column5054: She warned Coriolanus that his triumph over Rome would be a traitor's triumph, that his name would be "dogg'd with curses," and that his character would be summed up in history in one fatal sentence:                         The man was noble,   But with his last attempt he wiped it out,   Destroyed his country, and his name remains   To the ensuing age abhorr'd.
column5055: Mr. Whibley appears to loathe the mass of human beings so excessively that he does not quite realize the enormity (from the modern point of view) of Coriolanus's crime.
column5056: It would, I agree, be foolish to judge Coriolanus too scrupulously from a modern point of view.
column5057: But Mr. Whibley has asked us to accept the play as a tract for the times, and we must examine it as such in order to discover what Mr. Whibley means.
column5058: But, after all, Mr. Whibley's failure as a portrait-painter is a failure of the spirit even more than of the intellect.
column5059: A narrow spirit cannot comprehend a magnanimous spirit, and Mr. Whibley's imagination does not move in that large Shakespearean world in which illustrious men salute their mortal enemies in immortal sentences of praise after the manner of   He was the noblest Roman of them all.
column5060: The author who is capable of writing Mr. Whibley's character-study of Fox does not understand enough about the splendour and the miseries of human nature to write well on Shakespeare.
column5061: Of Fox Mr. Whibley says:     He put no bounds upon his hatred of England, and he thought it not     shameful to intrigue with foreigners against the safety and credit     of the land to which he belonged.
column5062: Wherever there was a foe to     England, there was a friend of Fox.
column5063: America, Ireland, France, each     in turn inspired his enthusiasm.
column5064: When Howe was victorious at     Brooklyn, he publicly deplored "the terrible news."
column5065: After Valmy he     did not hesitate to express his joy.
column5066: "No public event," he wrote,     "not excepting Yorktown and Saratoga, ever happened that gave me so     much delight.
column5067: I could not allow myself to believe it for some days     for fear of disappointment."
column5068: It does not seem to occur to Mr. Whibley that in regard to America, Ireland, and France, Fox was, according to the standard of every ideal for which the Allies professed to fight, tremendously right, and that, were it not for Yorktown and Valmy, America and France would not in our own time have been great free nations fighting against the embattled Whibleys of Germany.
column5069: So far as Mr. Whibley's political philosophy goes, I see no reason why he should not have declared himself on the side of Germany.
column5070: He believes in patriotism, it is true, but he is apparently a patriot of the sort that loves his country and hates his fellow-countrymen (if that is what he means by "the people," and presumably it must be).
column5071: Mr. Whibley has certainly the mind of a German professor.
column5072: His vehemence against the Germans for appreciating Shakespeare is strangely like a German professor's vehemence against the English for not appreciating him.
column5073: "Why then," he asks,     should the Germans have attempted to lay violent hands upon our     Shakespeare?
column5074: It is but part of their general policy of pillage.
column5075: Stealing comes as easy to them as it came to Bardolph and Nym, who     in Calais stole a fire-shovel.
column5076: Wherever they have gone they have     cast a thievish eye upon what does not belong to them.
column5077: They hit     upon the happy plan of levying tolls upon starved Belgium.
column5078: It was     not enough for their greed to empty a country of food; they must     extract something from its pocket, even though it be dying of     hunger.... No doubt, if they came to these shores, they would feed     their fury by scattering Shakespeare's dust to the winds of     heaven.
column5079: As they are unable to sack Stratford, they do what seems to     them the next best thing: they hoist the Jolly Roger over     Shakespeare's works.
column5080: Their arrogance is busy in vain.
column5082: He was an English patriot, who would always have refused to bow the     knee to an insolent alien.
column5083: This is mere foaming at the mouth--the tawdry violence of a Tory Thersites.
column5084: This passage is a measure of the good sense and imagination Mr. Whibley brings to the study of Shakespeare.
column5086: XV.--THE PERSONALITY OF MORRIS One thinks of William Morris as a man who wished to make the world as beautiful as an illuminated manuscript.
column5087: He loved the bright colours, the gold, the little strange insets of landscape, the exquisite craftsmanship of decoration, in which the genius of the medieval illuminators expressed itself.
column5088: His Utopia meant the restoration, not so much of the soul of man, as of the selected delights of the arts and crafts of the Middle Ages.
column5089: His passion for trappings--and what fine trappings!--is admirably suggested by Mr. Cunninghame Graham in his preface to Mr. Compton-Rickett's _William Morris: a Study in Personality_.
column5090: Morris he declares, was in his opinion "no mystic, but a sort of symbolist set in a medieval frame, and it appeared to me that all his love of the old times of which he wrote was chiefly of the setting; of tapestries well wrought; of needlework, rich colours of stained glass falling upon old monuments, and of fine work not scamped."
column5091: To emphasize the preoccupation of Morris with the very handiwork, rather than with the mystic secrets, of beauty is not necessarily to diminish his name.
column5092: He was essentially a man for whom the visible world existed, and in the manner in which he wore himself out in his efforts to reshape the visible world he proved himself one of the great men of his century.
column5093: His life was, in its own way, devotional ever since those years in which Burne-Jones, his fellow-undergraduate at Oxford, wrote to him: "We must enlist you in this Crusade and Holy Warfare against the age."
column5094: Like all revolutions, of course, the Morris revolution was a prophecy rather than an achievement.
column5095: But, perhaps, a prophecy of Utopia is itself one of the greatest achievements of which humanity is capable.
column5096: It is odd that one who spilled out his genius for the world of men should have been so self-sufficing, so little dependent on friendships and ordinary human relationships as Morris is depicted both in Mr. Mackail's biography and Mr. Compton-Rickett's study.
column5097: Obviously, he was a man with whom generosity was a second nature.
column5098: When he became a Socialist, he sold the greater part of his precious library in order to help the cause.
column5099: On the other hand, to balance this, we have Rossetti's famous assertion: "Top"--the general nickname for Morris--"never gives money to a beggar."
column5100: Mr. Mackail, if I remember right, accepted Rossetti's statement as expressive of Morris's indifference to men as compared with causes.
column5101: Mr. Compton-Rickett, however, challenges the truth of the observation.
column5102: "The number of 'beggars,'" he affirms, "who called at his house and went away rewarded were legion."
column5103: Mr. Belfort Bax declares that he kept a drawerful of half-crowns     for foreign anarchists, because, as he explained apologetically:     "They always wanted half-a-crown, and it saved time to have a stock     ready."
column5104: But this is no real contradiction of Rossetti.
column5105: Morris's anarchists represented his life's work to him.
column5106: He did not help them from that personal and irrational charity which made Rossetti want to give a penny to a beggar in the street.
column5107: This may be regarded as a supersubtle distinction; but it is necessary if we are to understand the important fact about Morris that--to quote Mr. Compton-Rickett--"human nature in the concrete never profoundly interested him."
column5108: Enthusiastic as were the friendships of his youth--when he gushed into "dearests" in his letters--we could imagine him as living without friends and yet being tolerably happy.
column5109: He was, as Mr. Compton-Rickett suggests, like a child with a new toy in his discovery of ever-fresh pursuits in the three worlds of Politics, Literature and Art.
column5110: He was a person to whom even duties were Pleasures.
column5111: Mr. Mackail has spoken of him as "the rare distance of a man who, without ever once swerving from truth or duty, knew what he liked and did what he liked, all his life long."
column5112: One thinks of him in his work as a child with a box of paints--an inspired child with wonderful paints and the skill to use them.
column5113: He was such a child as accepts companions with pleasure, but also accepts the absence of companions with pleasure.
column5114: He could absorb himself in his games of genius anywhere and everywhere.
column5115: "Much of his literary work was done on buses and in trains."
column5116: His poetry is often, as it were, the delightful nursery-work of a grown man.
column5117: "His best work," as Mr. Compton-Rickett says, "reads like happy improvisations."
column5118: He had a child's sudden and impulsive temper, too.
column5119: Once, having come into his studio in a rage, he "took a flying kick at the door, and smashed in a panel."
column5120: "It's all right," he assured the scared model, who was preparing to fly; "it's all right--_something_ had to give way."
column5121: The same violence of impulse is seen in the story of how, on one occasion, when he was staying in the country, he took an artistic dislike to his hostess's curtains, and tore them down during the night.
column5122: His judgments were often much the same kind of untempered emotions as he showed in the matter of the curtains--his complaint, for example, that a Greek temple was "like a table on four legs: a damned dull thing!"
column5123: He was a creature of whims: so much so that, as a boy, he used to have the curse, "Unstable as water, thou shalt not excel," flung at him.
column5124: He enjoyed the expression of knock-out opinions such as: "I always bless God for making anything so strong as an onion!"
column5125: He laughed easily, not from humour so much as from a romping playfulness.
column5126: He took a young boy's pleasure in showing off the strength of his mane of dark brown hair.
column5127: He would get a child to get hold of it, and lift him off the ground by it "with no apparent inconvenience."
column5128: He was at the same time nervous and restless.
column5129: He was given to talking to himself; his hands were never at peace; "if he read aloud, he punched his own head in the exuberance of his emotions."
column5130: Possibly there was something high-strung even about his play, as when, Mr. Mackail tells us, "he would imitate an eagle with considerable skill and humour, climbing on to a chair and, after a sullen pause, coming down with a soft, heavy flop."
column5131: It seems odd that Mr. John Burns could say of this sensitive and capricious man of genius, as we find him saying in Mr. Compton-Rickett's book, that "William Morris was a chunk of humanity in the rough; he was a piece of good, strong, unvarnished oak--nothing of the elm about him."
column5132: But we can forgive Mr. Burns's imperfect judgment in gratitude for the sentences that follow:     There is no side of modern life which he has not touched for good.
column5133: I am sure he would have endorsed heartily the House and Town     Planning Act for which I am responsible.
column5134: Morris, by the way, would have appreciated Mr. Burns's reference to him as a fellow-craftsman: did he not once himself boast of being "a master artisan, if I may claim that dignity"?
column5135: The buoyant life of this craftsman-preacher--whose craftsmanship, indeed, was the chief part of his preaching--who taught the labourers of his age, both by precept and example, that the difference between success and failure in life was the difference between being artisans of loveliness and poor hackworkers of profitable but hideous things--has a unique attractiveness in the history of the latter half of the nineteenth century.
column5136: He is a figure of whom we cannot be too constantly and vividly reminded.
column5137: When I took up Mr. Compton-Rickett's book I was full of hope that it would reinterpret for a new generation Morris's evangelistic personality and ideals.
column5138: Unfortunately, it contains very little of importance that has not already appeared in Mr. Mackail's distinguished biography; and the only interpretation of first-rate interest in the book occurs in the bold imaginative prose of Mr. Cunninghame Graham's introduction.
column5139: More than once the author tells us the same things as Mr. Mackail, only in a less life-like way.
column5140: For example, where Mr. Mackail says of Morris that "by the time he was seven years old he had read all the Waverley novels, and many of Marryat's," Mr. Compton-Rickett vaguely writes: "He was suckled on Romance, and knew his Scott and Marryat almost before he could lisp their names."
column5141: That is typical of Mr. Compton-Rickett's method.
column5142: Instead of contenting himself with simple and realistic sentences like Mr. Mackail's, he aims at--and certainly achieves--a kind of imitative picturesqueness.
column5143: We again see his taste for the high-flown in such a paragraph as that which tells us that "a common bond unites all these men--Dickens, Carlyle, Ruskin and Morris.
column5144: They differed in much; but, like great mountains lying apart in the base, they converge high up in the air."
column5145: The landscape suggested in these sentences is more topsy-turvy than the imagination likes to dwell upon.
column5146: And the criticisms in the book are seldom lightning-flashes of revelation.
column5147: For instance:     A more polished artistry we find in Tennyson; a greater     intellectual grip in Browning; a more haunting magic in Rossetti;     but for easy mastery over his material and general diffusion of     beauty Morris has no superior.
column5148: That, apart from the excellent "general diffusion of beauty," is the kind of conventional criticism that might pass in a paper read to a literary society.
column5149: But somehow, in a critic who deliberately writes a book, we look for a greater and more personal mastery of his authors than Mr. Compton-Rickett gives evidence of in the too facile eloquence of these pages.
column5150: The most interesting part of the book is that which is devoted to personalia.
column5151: But even in the matter of personalia Mr. Cunninghame Graham tells us more vital things in a page of his introduction than Mr. Compton-Rickett scatters through a chapter.
column5152: His description of Morris's appearance, if not a piece of heroic painting, gives us a fine grotesque design of the man:     His face was ruddy, and his hair inclined to red, and grew in waves     like water just before it breaks over a fall.
column5153: His beard was of the     same colour as his hair.
column5154: His eyes were blue and fiery.
column5155: His teeth,     small and irregular, but white except upon the side on which he hew     his pipe, where they were stained with brown.
column5156: When he walked he     swayed a little, not like (_sic_) a sailor sways, but as a man who     lives a sedentary life toddles a little in his gait.
column5157: His ears were     small, his nose high and well-made, his hands and feet small for a     man of his considerable bulk.
column5158: His speech and address were fitting     the man; bold, bluff, and hearty....
column5159: He was quick-tempered and     irritable, swift to anger and swift to reconciliation, and I should     think never bore malice in his life.
column5160: When he talked he seldom looked at you, and his hands were always     twisting, as if they wished to be at work.
column5161: Such was the front the man bore.
column5162: The ideal for which he lived may be summed up, in Mr. Compton-Rickett's expressive phrase, as "the democratization of beauty."
column5163: Or it may be stated more humanly in the words which Morris himself spoke at the grave of a young man who died of injuries received at the hands of the police in Trafalgar Square on "Bloody Sunday."
column5164: "Our friend," he then said:     Our friend who lies here has had a hard life, and met with a hard     death; and, if society had been differently constituted, his life     might have been a delightful, a beautiful, and a happy one.
column5165: It is     our business to begin to organize for the purpose of seeing that     such things shall not happen; to try and make this earth a     beautiful and happy place.
column5166: There you have the sum of all Morris's teaching.
column5167: Like so many fine artists since Plato, he dreamed of a society which would be as beautiful as a work of art.
column5168: He saw the future of society as a radiant picture, full of the bright light of hope, as he saw the past of society as a picture steeped in the charming lights of fancy.
column5169: He once explained Rossetti's indifference to politics by saying that he supposed "it needs a person of hopeful mind to take disinterested notice of politics, and Rossetti was certainly not hopeful."
column5170: Morris was the very illuminator of hope.
column5171: He was as hopeful a man as ever set out with words and colours to bring back the innocent splendours of the Golden Age.
column5172: XVI.--GEORGE MEREDITH (1) THE EGOIST George Meredith, as his friends used to tell one with amusement, was a vain man.
column5173: Someone has related how, in his later years, he regarded it as a matter of extreme importance that his visitors should sit in a position from which they would see his face in profile.
column5174: This is symbolic of his attitude to the world.
column5175: All his life he kept one side of his face hidden.
column5176: Mr. Ellis, who is the son of one of Meredith's cousins, now takes us for a walk round Meredith's chair.
column5177: No longer are we permitted to remain in restful veneration of "a god and a Greek."
column5178: Mr. Ellis invites us--and we cannot refuse the invitation--to look at the other side of the face, to consider the full face and the back of the head.
column5179: He encourages us to feel Meredith's bumps, and no man whose bumps we are allowed to feel can continue for five minutes the pretence of being an Olympian.
column5180: He becomes a human being under a criticizing thumb.
column5181: We discover that he had a genius for imposture, an egoist's temper, and a stomach that fluttered greedily at the thought of dainty dishes.
column5182: We find all those characteristics that prevented him from remaining on good terms first with his father, next with his wife, and then with his son.
column5183: At first, when one reads the full story of Meredith's estrangements through three generations, one has the feeling that one is in the presence of an idol in ruins.
column5184: Certainly, one can never mistake Box Hill for Olympus again.
column5185: On the other hand, let us but have time to accustom ourselves to see Meredith in other aspects than that which he himself chose to present to his contemporaries--let us begin to see in him not so much one of the world's great comic censors, as one of the world's great comic subjects, and we shall soon find ourselves back among his books, reading them no longer with tedious awe, but with a new passion of interest in the figure-in-the-background of the complex human being who wrote them.
column5186: For Meredith was his own great subject.
column5187: Had he been an Olympian he could not have written _The Egoist_ or _Harry Richmond_.
column5188: He was an egoist and pretender, coming of a line of egoists and pretenders, and his novels are simply the confession and apology of such a person.
column5189: Meredith concealed the truth about himself in his daily conversation; he revealed it in his novels.
column5190: He made such a mystery about his birth that many people thought he was a cousin of Queen Victoria's or at least a son of Bulwer Lytton's.
column5191: It was only in _Evan Harrington_ that he told the essentials of the truth about the tailor's shop in Portsmouth above which he was born.
column5192: Outside his art, nothing would persuade him to own up to the tailor's shop.
column5193: Once, when Mr. Clodd was filling in a census-paper for him, Meredith told him to put "near Petersfield" as his place of birth.
column5194: The fact that he was born at Portsmouth was not publicly known, indeed, until some time after his death.
column5195: And not only was there the tailor's shop to live down, but on his mother's side he was the grandson of a publican, Michael Macnamara.
column5196: Meredith liked to boast that his mother was "pure Irish"--an exaggeration, according to Mr. Ellis--but he said nothing about Michael Macnamara of "The Vine."
column5197: At the same time it was the presence not of a bar sinister but of a yardstick sinister in his coat of arms that chiefly filled him with shame.
column5198: When he was marrying his first wife he wrote "Esquire" in the register as a description of his father's profession.
column5199: There is no evidence, apparently, as to whether Meredith himself ever served in the tailor's shop after his father moved from Portsmouth to St. James's Street, London.
column5200: Nothing is known of his life during the two years after his return from the Moravian school at Neuwied.
column5201: As for his hapless father (who had been trained as a medical student but went into the family business in order to save it from ruin), he did not succeed in London any better than in Portsmouth, and in 1849 he emigrated to South Africa and opened a shop in Cape Town.
column5202: It was while in Cape Town that he read Meredith's ironical comedy on the family tailordom, _Evan Harrington; or He Would be a Gentleman_.
column5203: Naturally, he regarded the book (in which his father and himself were two of the chief figures) with horror.
column5204: It was as though George had washed the family tape-measure in public.
column5205: Augustus Meredith, no less than George, blushed for the tape-measure daily.
column5206: Probably, Melchizedek Meredith, who begat Augustus, who begat George, had also blushed for it in his day.
column5207: As the "great Mel" in _Evan Harrington_ he is an immortal figure of genteel imposture.
column5208: His lordly practice of never sending in a bill was hardly that of a man who accepted the conditions of his trade.
column5209: In _Evan Harrington_ three generations of a family's shame were held up to ridicule.
column5210: No wonder that Augustus Meredith, when he was congratulated by a customer on his son's fame, turned away silently with a look of pain.
column5211: The comedy of the Meredith family springs, of course, not from the fact that they were tailors, but that they pretended not to be tailors.
column5212: Whether Meredith himself was more ashamed of their tailoring or their pretentiousness it is not easy to decide.
column5213: Both _Evan Harrington_ and _Harry Richmond_ are in a measure, comedies of imposture, in which the vice of imposture is lashed as fiercely as Molière lashes the vice of hypocrisy in _Tartuffe_.
column5214: But it may well be that in life Meredith was a snob, while in art he was a critic of snobs.
column5215: Mr. Yeats, in his last book of prose, put forward the suggestion that the artist reveals in his art not his "self" (which is expressed in his life), but his "anti-self," a complementary and even contrary self.
column5216: He might find in the life and works of Meredith some support for his not quite convincing theory.
column5217: Meredith was an egoist in his life, an anti-egoist in his books.
column5218: He was pretentious in his life, anti-pretentious in his books.
column5219: He took up the attitude of the wronged man in his life; he took up the case of the wronged woman in his books.
column5220: In short, his life was vehemently pro-George-Meredith, while his books were vehemently anti-George-Meredith.
column5221: He knew himself more thoroughly, so far as we can discover from his books, than any other English novelist has ever done.
column5222: He knew himself comically, no doubt, rather than tragically.
column5223: In _Modern Love_ and _Richard Feverel_ he reveals himself as by no means a laughing philosopher; but he strove to make fiction a vehicle of philosophic laughter rather than of passionate sympathy.
column5224: Were it not that a great poetic imagination is always at work--in his prose, perhaps, even more than in his verse--his genius might seem a little cold and head-in-the-air.
column5225: But his poet's joy in his characters saves his books from inhumanity.
column5226: As Diana Warwick steps out in the dawn she is not a mere female human being undergoing critical dissection; she is bird-song and the light of morning and the coming of the flowers.
column5227: Meredith had as great a capacity for rapture as for criticism and portraiture.
column5228: He has expressed in literature as no other novelist has done the rapturous vision of a boy in love.
column5229: He knew that a boy in love is not mainly a calf but a poet.
column5230: _Love in a Valley_ is the incomparable music of a boy's ecstasy.
column5231: Much of _Richard Feverel_ is its incomparable prose.
column5232: Rapture and criticism, however, make a more practical combination in literature than in life.
column5233: In literature, criticism may add flavour to rapture; in life it is more than likely to destroy the flavour.
column5234: One is not surprised, then, to learn the full story of Meredith's first unhappy marriage.
column5235: A boy of twenty-one, he married a widow of thirty, high-strung, hot and satirical like himself; and after a depressing sequence of dead babies, followed by the birth of a son who survived, she found life with a man of genius intolerable, and ran away with a painter.
column5236: Meredith apparently refused her request to go and see her when she was dying.
column5237: His imaginative sympathy enabled him to see the woman's point of view in poetry and fiction; it does not seem to have extended to his life.
column5238: Thus, his biography is to a great extent a "showing-up" of George Meredith.
column5239: He proved as incapable of keeping the affection of his son Arthur, as of keeping that of his wife.
column5240: Much as he loved the boy he had not been married again long before he allowed him to become an alien presence.
column5241: The boy felt he had a grievance.
column5242: He said--probably without justice--that his father kept him short of money.
column5243: Possibly he was jealous for his dead mother's sake.
column5244: Further, though put into business, he had literary ambitions--a prolific source of bitterness.
column5245: When Arthur died, Meredith did not even attend his funeral.
column5246: Mr. Ellis has shown Meredith up not only as a husband and a father, but as a hireling journalist and a lark-devouring gourmet.
column5247: On the whole, the poet who could eat larks in a pie seems to me to be a more shocking "great man" than the Radical who could write Tory articles in a newspaper for pay.
column5248: At the same time, it is only fair to say that Meredith remains a sufficiently splendid figure in.
column5249: Mr. Ellis's book even when we know the worst about him.
column5251: It was at least a prodigal one.
column5252: As poet, novelist, correspondent, and conversationalist, he leaves an impression of beauty, wit, and power in a combination without a precedent.
column5253: (2) THE OLYMPIAN UNBENDS Lady Butcher's charming _Memoirs of George Meredith_ is admittedly written in reply to Mr. Ellis's startling volume.
column5254: It seems to me, however, that it is a supplement rather than a reply.
column5255: Mr. Ellis was not quite fair to Meredith as a man, but he enabled us to understand the limitations which were the conditions of Meredith's peculiar genius.
column5256: Many readers were shocked by the suggestion that characters, like countries, must have boundaries.
column5257: Where Mr. Ellis failed, in my opinion, was not in drawing these as carefully as possible, but in the rather unfriendly glee with which, one could not help feeling, he did so.
column5258: It is also true that he missed some of the grander mountain-peaks in Meredith's character.
column5259: Lady Butcher, on the other hand, is far less successful than Mr. Ellis in drawing a portrait which makes us feel that now we understand something of the events that gave birth to _The Egoist_ and _Richard Feverel_ and _Modern Love_.
column5260: Her book tells us nothing of the seed-time of genius, but is a delightful account of its autumn.
column5261: At the same time it helps to dissipate one ridiculous popular fallacy about Meredith.
column5262: Meredith, like most all the wits, has been accused of straining after image and epigram.
column5263: Wit acts as an irritant on many people.
column5264: They forget the admirable saying of Coleridge: "Exclusive of the abstract sciences, the largest and worthiest portion of our knowledge consists of aphorisms; and the greatest of men is but an aphorism."
column5265: They might as well denounce a hedge for producing wild roses or a peacock for growing tail feathers with pretty eyes as a witty writer for flowering into aphorism, epigram and image.
column5266: Even so artificial a writer as Wilde had not to labour to be witty.
column5267: It has often been laid to his charge that his work smells of the lamp, whereas what is really the matter with it is that it smells of the drawing-room gas.
column5268: It was the result of too much "easy-goingness," not of too much strain.
column5269: As for Meredith, his wit was the wit of an abounding imagination.
column5270: Lady Butcher gives some delightful examples of it.
column5271: He could not see a baby in long robes without a witty image leaping into his mind.
column5272: He said he adored babies "in the comet stage."
column5273: Of a lady of his acquaintance he said: "She is a woman who has never had the first tadpole wriggle of an idea," adding, "She has a mind as clean and white and flat as a plate: there are no eminences in it."
column5274: Lady Butcher tells of a picnic-party on Box Hill at which Meredith was one of the company.
column5275: "After our picnic ... it came on to rain, and as we drearily trudged down the hill with cloaks and umbrellas, and burdened with our tea baskets, Mr. Meredith, with a grimace, called out to a passing friend: 'Behold!
column5277: If Meredith is to some extent an obscure author, it is clear that this was not due to his over-reaching himself in laborious efforts after wit.
column5278: His obscurity is not that of a man straining after expression, but the obscurity of a man deliberately hiding something.
column5279: Meredith believed in being as mysterious as an oracle.
column5280: He assumed the Olympian manner, and objected to being mistaken for a frequenter of the market-place.
column5281: He was impatient of ordinary human witlessness, and spoke to his fellows, not as man to man, but as Apollo from his seat.
column5282: This was probably a result of the fact that his mind marched much too fast for the ordinary man to keep pace with it.
column5283: "How I leaped through leagues of thought when I could walk!"
column5284: he once said when he had lost the power of his legs.
column5285: Such buoyancy of the imagination and intellect separated him more and more from a world in which most of the athletics are muscular, not mental; and he began to take a malicious pleasure in exaggerating the difference that already existed between himself and ordinary mortals.
column5286: He dressed his genius in a mannerism, and, as he leaped through his leagues of thought, the flying skirts of his mannerism were all that the average reader panting desperately after him could see.
column5287: Shakespeare and the greatest men of genius are human enough to wait for us, and give us time to recover our breath.
column5288: Meredith, however, was a proud man, and a mocker.
column5289: In the ordinary affairs of life, Lady Butcher tells us, he was so proud that it was difficult to give him even trifling gifts.
column5290: "I remember," she says, "bringing him two silver flat poached-egg spoons from Norway, and he implored me to take them back with me to London, and looked much relieved when I consented to do so!"
column5291: He would always "prefer to bestow rather than to accept gifts."
column5292: Lady Butcher, replying to the charge that he was ungrateful, suggests that "no one should expect an eagle to be grateful."
column5293: But then, neither can one love an eagle, and one would like to be able to love the author of _Love in a Valley_ and _Richard Feverel_.
column5294: Meredith was too keenly aware what an eagle he was.
column5295: Speaking of the reviewers who had attacked him, he said: "They have always been abusing me.
column5298: It is quite true, but it was a superior person who said it.
column5299: Meredith, however, among his friends and among the young, loses this air of superiority, and becomes something of a radiant romp as well as an Olympian.
column5300: Lady Butcher's first meeting with him took place when she was a girl of thirteen.
column5301: She was going up Box Hill to see the sun rise with a sixteen-year-old cousin, when the latter said: "I know a madman who lives on Box Hill.
column5302: He's quite mad, but very amusing; he likes walks and sunrises.
column5303: Let's go and shout him up!"
column5304: It does Meredith credit that he got out of bed and joined them, "his nightshirt thrust into brown trousers."
column5305: Even when the small girl insisted on "reading aloud to him one of the hymns from Keble's _Christian Year_," he did not, as the saying is, turn a hair.
column5306: His attachment to his daughter Mariette--his "dearie girl," as he spoke of her with unaffected softness of phrase--also helps one to realize that he was not all Olympian.
column5307: Meredith, the condemner of the "guarded life," was humanly nervous in guarding his own little daughter.
column5308: "He would never allow Mariette to travel alone, even the very short distance by train from Box Hill to Ewell; a maid had always to be sent with her or to fetch her.
column5309: He never allowed her to walk by herself."
column5310: One likes Meredith the better for Lady Butcher's picture of him as a "harassed father."
column5311: One likes him, too, as he converses with his dogs, and for his thoughtfulness in giving some of his MSS., including that of _Richard Feverel_, to Frank Cole, his gardener, in the hope that "some day the gardener would be able to sell them" and so get some reward for his devotion.
column5312: As to the underground passages in Meredith's life and character, Lady Butcher is not concerned with them.
column5313: She writes of him merely as she knew him.
column5314: Her book is a friend's tribute, though not a blind tribute.
column5315: It may not be effective as an argument against those who are bent on disparaging the greatest lyrical wit in modern English literature.
column5316: But it will be welcomed by those for whom Meredith's genius is still a bubbling spring of good sense and delight.
column5317: (3) THE ANGLO-IRISH ASPECT Meredith never wrote a novel which was less a novel than _Celt and Saxon_.
column5318: It is only a fragment of a book.
column5319: It is so much a series of essays and sharp character-sketches, however, that the untimely fall of the curtain does not greatly trouble us.
column5320: There is no excitement of plot, no gripping anxiety as to whether this or that pair of lovers will ever reach the altar.
column5321: Philip O'Donnell and Patrick, his devoted brother, and their caricature relative, the middle-aged Captain Con, all interest us as they abet each other in the affairs of love or politics, or as they discuss their native country or the temperament of the country which oppresses it; but they are chiefly desirable as performers in an Anglo-Irish fantasia, a Meredithian piece of comic music, with various national anthems, English, Welsh, and Irish, running through and across it in all manner of guises, and producing all manner of agreeable disharmonies.
column5322: In the beginning we have Patrick O'Donnell, an enthusiast, a Celt, a Catholic, setting out for the English mansion of the father of Adiante Adister to find if the girl cannot be pleaded over to reconsider her refusal of his brother Philip.
column5323: He arrives in the midst of turmoil in the house, the cause of it being a hasty marriage which Adiante had ambitiously contracted with a hook-nosed foreign prince.
column5324: Patrick, a broken-hearted proxy, successfully begs her family for a miniature of the girl to take back to his brother, but he falls so deeply in love with her on seeing the portrait that his loyalty to Philip almost wavers, when the latter carelessly asks him to leave the miniature on a more or less public table instead of taking it off to the solitude of his own room for a long vigil of adoration.
column5325: In the rest of the story we have an account of the brothers in the London house of Captain Con, the happy husband married to a stark English wife of mechanical propriety--a rebellious husband, too, when in the sociable atmosphere of his own upper room, amid the blackened clay pipes and the friendly fumes of whiskey, he sings her praises, while at the same time full of grotesque and whimsical criticisms of all those things, Saxon and more widely human, for which she stands.
column5326: There is a touch of farce in the relations of these two, aptly symbolized by the bell which rings for Captain Con, and hastens him away from his midnight eloquence with Patrick and Philip.
column5328: I haven't heard the tinkler for months.
column5329: It signifies she's cold in her bed.
column5330: The thing called circulation is unknown to her save by the aid of outward application, and I'm the warming-pan, as legitimately as I should be, I'm her husband and her Harvey in one.'"
column5331: It is in the house of Captain Con, it should be added, that Philip and Patrick meet Jane Mattock, the Saxon woman; and the story as we have it ends with Philip invalided home from service in India, and Jane, a victim of love, catching "glimpses of the gulfs of bondage, delicious, rose-enfolded, foreign."
column5332: There are nearly three hundred pages of it altogether, some of them as fantastic and lyrical as any that Meredith ever wrote.
column5333: As one reads _Celt and Saxon_, however, one seems to get an inkling of the reason why Meredith has so often been set down as an obscure author.
column5334: It is not entirely that he is given to using imagery as the language of explanation--a subtle and personal sort of hieroglyphics.
column5335: It is chiefly, I think, because there is so little direct painting of men and women in his books.
column5336: Despite his lyricism, he had something of an X-ray's imagination.
column5337: The details of the modelling of a face, the interpreting lines and looks, did not fix themselves with preciseness on his vision enabling him to pass them on to us with the surface reality we generally demand in prose fiction.
column5338: It is as though he painted some of his men and women upon air: they are elusive for all we know of their mental and spiritual processes.
column5339: Even though he is at pains to tell us that Diana's hair is dark, we do not at once accept the fact but are at liberty to go on believing she is a fair woman, for he himself was general rather than insistently particular in his vision of such matters.
column5340: In the present book, again, we have a glimpse of Adiante in her miniature--"this lighted face, with the dark raised eyes and abounding auburn tresses, where the contrast of colours was in itself thrilling," "the light above beauty distinguishing its noble classic lines and the energy of radiance, like a morning of chivalrous promise, in the eyes"--and, despite the details mentioned, the result is to give us only the lyric aura of the woman where we wanted a design.
column5341: Ultimately, these women of Meredith's become intensely real to us--the most real women, I think, in English fiction--but, before we come to handshaking terms with them, we have sometimes to go to them over bogs and rocky places with the sun in our eyes.
column5342: Before this, physically, they are apt to be exquisite parts of a landscape, sharers of a lyric beauty with the cherry-trees and the purple crocuses.
column5343: Coming to the substance of the book--the glance from many sides at the Irish and English temperaments--we find Meredith extremely penetrating in his criticism of John Bullishness, but something of a foreigner in his study of the Irish character.
column5344: The son of an Irishwoman, he chose an Irishwoman as his most conquering heroine, but he writes of the race as one who has known the men and women of it entirely, or almost entirely, in an English setting--a setting, in other words, which shows up their strangeness and any surface eccentricities they may have, but does not give us an ordinary human sense of them.
column5345: Captain Con is vital, because Meredith imagined him vitally, but when all is said and done, he is largely a stage-Irishman, winking over his whiskey that has paid no excise--a better-born relative of Captain Costigan.
column5346: Politically, _Celt and Saxon_ seems to be a plea for Home Rule--Home Rule, with a view towards a "consolidation of the union."
column5347: Its diagnosis of the Irish difficulty is one which has long been popular with many intellectual men on this side of the Irish Sea.
column5348: Meredith sees, as the roots of the trouble, misunderstanding, want of imagination, want of sympathy.
column5349: It has always seemed curious to me that intelligent men could persuade themselves that Ireland was chiefly suffering from want of understanding and want of sympathy on the part of England, when all the time her only ailment has been want of liberty.
column5350: To adapt the organ-grinder's motto,   Sympathy without relief   Is like mustard without beef.
column5351: As a matter of fact, Meredith realized this, and was a friend to many Irish national movements from the Home Rule struggle down to the Gaelic League, to the latter of which the Irish part of him sent a subscription a year or two ago.
column5352: He saw things from the point of view of an Imperial Liberal idealist, however, not of a Nationalist.
column5353: In the result, he did not know the every-day and traditional setting of Irish life sufficiently well to give us an Irish Nationalist central figure as winning and heroic, even in his extravagances, as, say, the patriotic Englishman, Neville Beauchamp.
column5354: At the same time, one must be thankful for a book so obviously the work of a great abundant mind--a mind giving out its criticisms like flutters of birds--a heroic intellect always in the service of an ideal liberty, courage, and gracious manners--a characteristically island brain, that was yet not insular.
column5355: XVII--OSCAR WILDE Oscar Wilde is a writer whom one must see through in order to appreciate.
column5356: One must smash the idol in order to preserve the god.
column5357: If Mr. Ransome's estimate of Wilde in his clever and interesting and seriously-written book is a little unsatisfactory, it is partly because he is not enough of an iconoclast.
column5358: He has not realized with sufficient clearness that, while Wilde belonged to the first rank as a wit, he was scarcely better than second-rate as anything else.
column5359: Consequently, it is not Wilde the beau of literature who dominates his book.
column5360: Rather, it is Wilde the egoistic,--æsthetic philosopher, and Wilde the imaginative artist.
column5361: This is, of course, as Wilde would have liked it to be.
column5362: For, as Mr. Ransome says, "though Wilde had the secret of a wonderful laughter, he preferred to think of himself as a person with magnificent dreams."
column5363: Indeed, so much was this so, that it is even suggested that, if _Salomé_ had not been censored, the social comedies might never have been written.
